item.title: About Arian & Karen
item.description:
Arian and Karen are living in eSwatini (formerly Swaziland) for a year as part of a Peace Corps Response project with the Ministry of Health to develop their electronic medical records (EMR/EHR) system.

It should be pointed out that everything they say is their own and not, in any way, endorsed by the Peace Corps or US Government.

Our son Damian and his wife Lilly will be living in Tome, Japan for a year with the Japanese Exchange and Teaching (JET) program with Lilly teaching in some local schools while Damian continues with his current job as a remote worker.

Our son Gabriel and his wife Kendrea spent a semester abroad (August ‚Äì December) in Nepal near Boudhanath, on the outskirts of Kathmandu, where classes were held at a Tibetan Buddhist monastery. They have since returned home.

item.title: About Damian & Lilly
item.description:
Damian and Lilly finished their degrees at Oregon State University, got married, and are heading to Japan; it‚Äôs been a busy year!

Lilly was accepted into the Japanese Exchange and Teaching (JET) program and placed in Tome, Japan. She‚Äôll be primarily teaching elementary schoolers at Minamikata Elementary School, though she‚Äôll make weekly and monthly trips to 2 other elementary schools and 2 kindergartens for a total of 5 schools. Lilly is the first full time JET Assistant Language Teacher (ALT) that Minamikata Elementary has had.

Damian is continuing to work for Citycounty Insurance Services (CIS). The time difference means that he has to wake up really early to have 4 hours of overlap with Oregon. Since CIS is for Oregon cities and counties, they were a little unsure of having a remote worker from Japan but it‚Äôs been working out so far! Damian also didn‚Äôt have any Japanese skills upon first arriving. He has to spend a lot of time learning the various written languages used here as well as trying to learn the culture.

We‚Äôll be in Tome for a full year, returning around mid-late August 2020.

Feel free to come visit us if you want!

item.title: About Gabriel & Kendrea
item.description:
Biography

Hello! We‚Äôre Kendrea and Gabriel Kulp.

Kendrea is a third-year student at Oregon State University majoring in Computer Science and Philosophy and minoring in Mathematics; she‚Äôs interested in computer ethics and Effective Altruism. Gabriel is a fourth-year student at OSU majoring in Computer Science and minoring in Mathematics and Physics; he‚Äôs interested in computer security and its relationship with civil liberties.

We enjoy singing, playing musical instruments, messing around with computers, unicycling, interacting with various living creatures, and taking naps. We got married in July 2019, almost exactly a month before leaving for Nepal.

Glossary

Places

  • Boudhanath (Boudha) ‚Äì The Tibetan district of Kathmandu. Home of our host family and many monasteries, including Ka-Nying Shedrub Ling. Famous for the Boudhanath Stupa.
  • Himalayas ‚Äì The mountains that form the north border of Nepal.
  • Ka-Nying Shedrub Ling ‚Äì The monastery that hosts RYI.
  • Kathmandu ‚Äì The capital city of Nepal. The elevation is a bit lower than that of Denver, CO.
  • Oregon State University (OSU) ‚Äì Our home university.
  • Rangjung Yeshe Institute (RYI) ‚Äì The international school that operates within the monastery. RYI is associated with Kathmandu University, which provides credit for our classes.
  • Tibet ‚Äì A mountainous region in western China, separated from Nepal by the Himalayas. The Chinese government suppresses the traditional Buddhist, nomadic culture, so many Tibetans have moved elsewhere ‚Äî many to Nepal ‚Äî to practice their lifestyle in peace.

People

  • Geoff Barstow (Dr. Barstow) ‚Äì The Oregon State University professor who organizes this study abroad. He studies vegetarianism in Tibetan Buddhism.

item.title: Acclimating
item.description:
For me, the last couple of weeks have been focused around work and trying to understand the nuances of the project at hand. Understandably, making improvements to the national health information system is an enormous task. There are a dizzying number of pressing issues to address and that makes prioritization a challenge. Next week I will travel to an outlying health facility to observe how clinical staff are trained to use the current version of the electronic health record software. That will definitely be interesting to see!

Tomorrow there is a Trade Fair in a nearby town. Hopefully that will provide lots of opportunities for photos. Then on Monday we will have a day off from work for a national holiday. We are planning to attend the festivities with some of our fellow Peace Corps volunteers. As much as I am eager to dig into the work, I am happy to have the opportunity to relax a bit and see more of the country.

item.title: Busy roadsides
item.description:
I thought I‚Äôd use this post to talk about something interesting I‚Äôve noticed here. The country is relatively poor, with most people making less than $1 USD/day, but there is no end to the entrepreneurial spirit. Pretty much every roadside is dotted with various vendor stalls. Stands with roasted corn, fruit, salty snacks, and grilled meats to eat, buckets and water tanks, and the ever-present MTN data/airtime cards can be found all over the place. Other stands offer car washes, haircuts, or cell phone repair. Most of the stands are built out of poles (4-5‚Ä≥ diameter), pallets, or corrugated metal, or just the back of a truck.

It‚Äôs super cool to see the many ways people find to make money. Crime is relatively low, despite the poverty, and instead lots of individual businesses abound. Even at work, it seems many people have a side hustle. Pay is low, even for professional jobs, so they are always on the lookout for opportunities.

The variety of items for sale includes clothing, shoes, soap, jewelry, hats, and much more. I‚Äôd love to publish more pictures, but it‚Äôs kind of hard to get images without asking lots of people for permission! I try to be sneaky and get shots when people are facing away, but that‚Äôs not always an option. If I can get more in the future, I‚Äôd love to post more!

item.title: Busy times in Eswatini!
item.description:
I‚Äôve been meaning to get to a post for a few weeks now, but it keeps getting pushed aside due to conflicting priorities. We‚Äôve been hard at work trying to bring updates to CMIS (Client Management Information System), Eswatini‚Äôs EMR (Electronic Medical Records system). This involves adding new requested features, rearranging the code base to best support our needs, and working through bugs (existing ones and ones we‚Äôve introduced!).

This week we‚Äôve spent hours inside and outside of work prototyping some new features for the system. Currently, CMIS is primarily used in almost 200 clinics for outpatient work, that is, visits that don‚Äôt involve checking into a hospital. Many of these clinics focus on HIV, TB, or other diseases, while also providing other regular medical services. Supporting the needs of an inpatient facility (a hospital) requires a very different way of working with the system, but is necessary to offer the best care at all points of service. There are still very many scenarios that require paper forms to capture data within a facility or to transfer information about a patient between facilities. No more paper!

All next week we will be participating in sessions with various stakeholders (doctors, nurses, regional representatives) as we try to come to consensus about some of these changes to make sure that we have buy-in for what‚Äôs likely to be some new ways of doing things in the system. Clinicians all have their own optimized workflows to deal with their patient load, and introducing an EMR (no matter how good) will also slow things down at first. We are hoping that with enough input, we can minimize this friction and make it a positive thing.

In other news, the weather has continued to bounce up and down. On one day, sweating through my shirt on the way to work before 8am, then the next day wishing I had grabbed a jacket! There needs to be some work toward better weather management. I haven‚Äôt figured out who to complain to yet‚Ä¶

item.title: Changing With the Seasons
item.description:
The weather has turned, and with it, life is gently transitioning.

Our host grandma has gotten sick with a cold. She constantly tells us to eat lots of hot food, wear sweaters, and wear slippers so that our feet don‚Äôt touch the cold marble. The temperature is‚Ä¶ in the high 60s (Fahrenheit). Not so cold by Oregon standards!

As we reach the end of monsoon season, the mosquitos that carry dengue will disappear. We‚Äôve asked maybe ten (!) pharmacies if they have any bug repellent left, and all but one have said no. It looks like our little lavender-scented spray bottle will persevere long enough.

Last Monday, it felt like the right time to get haircuts. My hair now dries much faster, stays out of my way, and (I think) looks pretty nifty! Gabriel briefly had a smooth face, but it yearns to remain hairy, so he already has a solid crop of stubble.

How this hair length came to be: We ducked into the first barber shop we saw. The dude who cut my hair looked about 16, he didn‚Äôt speak any English, and he clearly had very little experience. Despite these obstacles, both of my ears are intact. Gabriel‚Äôs barber pulled Gabriel‚Äôs face all over the place and spread many foamy substances on it. We were both treated to head and back massages afterward: they stretched our arms, popped our knuckles, and whacked us on the head with fists. We were surprised at all the physical contact, because Nepalis will usually never touch another person‚Äôs head, especially of someone of the opposite gender. As my mom said, maybe the 16-year-old enjoyed giving me a massage more than I enjoyed receiving it‚Ä¶ Anyway, at the end, I saw a poster in Devanagari and figured out that it advertised haircuts for $1 (100 Nepali rupees), not $5 as they had told us. I kept quiet, figuring that this was still a good deal. I paid $10 (to cover both of us) and tried to leave, but then a barber asked for $7 more for the shave! Now that they were really trying to overcharge us, I pointed out the low price on the poster, and they let us go. I‚Äôm glad that we 1) gave them a tip because we could afford it, 2) didn‚Äôt let them totally rip us off, and best of all, 3) showed that foreigners might know more than they let on üòâ

As of September 18, we‚Äôve been married as long in Nepal as in the United States!

Yesterday, we had a lovely time visiting Yuki‚Äôs apartment with Mesa and Jesus. We folded origami cranes for Mesa‚Äôs friend, who has cancer, as we chatted and I read an Anthropology textbook chapter out loud.

I jotted down the nationalities of all of my Ethics classmates. (Since then, I‚Äôve switched out of Ethics, but these proportions are pretty representative.)

Things are going well. We‚Äôre glad we switched into different classes ‚Äî the new ones are much more engaging and relevant to us. item.title: What We‚Äôre Here For: Classes
item.description:
Now that we have four weeks of school behind us, we can share a more holistic view of what we‚Äôre studying!

Our classmates are super diverse, not only in country of origin, but also educational background. Many have been devout Buddhists for years. Many new students have never written academic papers. Some have undergraduate degrees in Buddhist Studies and are here to get graduate degrees. Some are monks and nuns who memorize religious texts on a regular basis. Some older people have left careers in the West to deepen their religious practice. The vast majority speak English as a second language. I‚Äôm amazed that it works to cram us all in the same classroom and give us the same assignments.

Khenpo Class

We have Khenpo class (a.k.a. Textual Studies 101, taught by a highly educated Tibetan monk) every day for 1.5 hours, plus a weekly 1-hour review class with the translator. (Side note: we enjoy hearing the translator speak Tibetan with Khenpo with her strong Russian accent.) We study one book ‚Äî Shantideva‚Äôs Bodhisattvacharyavatara ‚Äî line by line. When we leave after four months of study, we will only be halfway through the book! Along the way, we draw on Tibetan Buddhist commentaries to learn theories, terms, lists, and more.

‚ÄúBodhisattvacharyavatara‚Äù translates to ‚ÄúThe Way of the Bodhisattva‚Äù. A bodhisattva is a being who generates bodhicitta, the wish to attain enlightenment for the sake of liberating all sentient beings from the painful cycle of rebirth. The goal in the Mahayana tradition, the largest branch of Buddhism, is to become an enlightened bodhisattva. Shantideva wrote this foundational text in the eighth century to guide ordinary beings on the bodhisattva path. Speaking of the bodhisattva path, here‚Äôs a chart I made that gives a good idea of the depth we‚Äôre going into:

RYI‚Äôs Textual Studies courses are taught in the traditional format, in which monastics teach monastics. Therefore, even though Khenpo and the translator carefully accommodate the non-Buddhists in the class (nobody‚Äôs trying to convert us, we promise!), the structure of the course assumes a Buddhist audience. Consequently, we pray at the beginning and end of the class, and we‚Äôre required to memorize (I think) 30 verses of the text. Here‚Äôs a representative verse:

Should bodhicitta come to birth Revered by all the world, by gods and humankind.

And here‚Äôs the dedication prayer we say in Tibetan at the end of the class:

Nepali Language

RYI takes its language classes seriously! We hear that Colloquial Tibetan, Classical Tibetan, and Sanskrit classes are much more difficult than Nepali, but we‚Äôre still working hard. We have an hour of ‚ÄúMaster Class‚Äù with our lovely professor three times a week, an hour of one-on-one practice with native speakers twice a week, and an hour of ‚ÄúBoost Class‚Äù with four students and two native speakers once a week. That‚Äôs a total of six hours of language class every week. Since the class sizes are so small, we‚Äôre constantly put on the spot to speak individually. With all the classes, homework, daily life with a Nepali host family, and interactions with Nepali people around town, we‚Äôre learning pretty quickly.

Fun Facts

  • ‚ÄúKendrea‚Äù means ‚Äúcentral‚Äù in Nepali and Hindi! Apparently it has positive connotations of mental concentration.
  • You can refer to others in either an honorific or informal way. A husband uses the informal pronoun for his wife. But‚Ä¶ a wife must use the honorific pronoun for her husband. I can understand using informal both ways (because spouses know each other well) or honorific both ways (because spouses should respect each other), but the inequality is pretty gross.
  • Dear Aunts Rennie, Ileana, Maria, and Ariadne: you are sisters of Gabriel‚Äôs father, so he can refer to each of you as ‚Äúphoopoo‚Äù üòâ

Anthropology

We regret to announce that Father Greg, our Buddhist Studies 205 professor, has been temporarily deported. The Nepali government bureaucracy makes it really difficult to maintain your visa! The class is supposed to take place for 1.5 hours twice a week, but we‚Äôve only had three or four classes so far. We‚Äôll write about it when we have more to say!

Philosophy

Finally, I‚Äôm taking Fundamentals of Buddhist Philosophy (a.k.a. Buddhist Studies 203) without Gabriel. In this class, we study emptiness. We read and discuss one academic paper and one sutra (story of the Buddha‚Äôs teachings) every week. This material is all pretty new to me and interesting!

I switched out of the prerequisite class, so I‚Äôm having a bit of a hard time keeping track of all the terms that our professor, a Frenchwoman with an impressive American accent, tosses around. Besides, because this is a 200-level class, my experience with academic writing isn‚Äôt unusual! I‚Äôm not too concerned, though. I‚Äôll just study a little harder and try to listen more than speak.

item.description:
Cooking! A necessity and an enjoyable pastime, and not one of the things I thought would be any different from the States. I wasn‚Äôt completely wrong, but not completely right either.

When we moved into our apartment, there were no appliances in it, at all. No stove, no fridge, no washing machine. Only a wall mounted air conditioner in the main room. There was a lowered section of counter meant for a counter top stove, you can kind of see it to Damian‚Äôs left in the picture above. There also was a space for the refrigerator, which was thankfully given to us a couple of days in along with a microwave. After a couple more weeks of instant food and cold lunches, we got a single electric induction burner!

It‚Äôs been interesting, slowly collecting the things we need to cook like we‚Äôre at home. In Japan people generally don‚Äôt bake anywhere near as much as we do in the States, with the preferred methods of cooking being grilling and boiling. Nearly everything here is cooked on the stove, and large ovens that we have in America that heat with flame or electric coils are impossible to find. Even if we were to find one there would be nowhere to put it!

In Japan what they have are basically souped up microwave-toasteroven-oven combos that use electricity to mimic the kind of direct heat you get with an oven or toaster oven. We gave in and bought one of these recently, and it‚Äôs really been a comfort to have. Aside from that, we do the majority of cooking on our two burner gas stove. It is very very hot, hotter than any gas range I‚Äôve used before, and it‚Äôs been challenging.

After going through all this trouble I think I can understand better why not many of the other ALTs here in Tome do much cooking, if any. If you already have terrible with cooking, coming to Japan will not make it any easier! Despite that, being able to have home cooked meals, especially some recipes from home, has been lovely. Nothing beats homesickness like the taste of home! Japanese food is delicious, but Japanese people do not spice their food nearly as liberally as we do! But I‚Äôll leave that for another post.

item.title: Coronavirus
item.description:
Hello everyone!

I‚Äôm writing this brief post to give everyone an update on the situation here in Japan. Some of you may have heard that Abe Shinzo, Japan‚Äôs prime minister, made an announcement last week that all of the schools in Japan would be closed for the next several weeks. It was really a suggestion, but as my school district decided to close school, you may be wondering what all this means for Damian and I.

For the most part, our day-to-day doesn‚Äôt really change. Damian isn‚Äôt affected at all, as he works from home, and I‚Äôm actually still going to work. School is closed for the kids, but teachers are actually still required to go in.

So, for the next month until the new school year, I‚Äôm going to be spending a lot of time at my desk. I will probably be doing prep, Japanese language study, and discreet reading. In all honesty, I‚Äôm probably going to be extremely bored for the next month until the new school year starts (The school year starts in April in Japan). However, I will still be working and it‚Äôs pretty much business as usual.

Damian and I are doing fine, and we‚Äôre mildly amused with the antics of some people overreacting to the situation.

Look forward to some older posts that we‚Äôve been working on! We‚Äôll be sure to keep everyone updated with the goings on out here.

item.title: Corvallis to Singapore
item.description:
We‚Äôre in Asia!

The adventure began on Thursday. I was feeling much better after finishing a two-week course of antibiotics that left me tired and nauseous. We finished up our two-week house-sitting gig by taking the elderly labradoodle, Tanner, on a lovely walk around the neighborhood.

We finished packing at my parents‚Äô house, and then my family escorted us to Portland by way of a healthy dinner out. We met up with Dr. Barstow, Mesa, and Kalie to trade stories over a leisurely second dinner (paid for by Dr. Barstow‚Äôs ridiculous frequent-flyer rewards).

We four hopped to San Francisco, then got on a gigantic Singapore Airlines plane for the 15-hour nighttime flight to Hong Kong. It certainly helped that the flight attendants handed out hot towels and two warm meals, but a flight that long is bound to be uncomfortable! (We‚Äôve eaten at least twice the usual number of meals for this timeframe‚Ä¶) We arrived at the Hong Kong airport without a single hitch. In fact, it was eerie that we saw zero signs of the recent protests. We had a layover long enough to go ‚ÄúWhoaaaa we‚Äôre in China‚Äù, and then we congregated again to return to the exact same seats. It‚Äôs a good thing, too! Turns out we‚Äôve had a super cool seatmate this entire time. Ananya is a junior (like me!) studying Computer Science, Data Science, and Product Design at UC Berkeley, and she‚Äôs headed home to Singapore. Just like the protagonist of the book I listened to while sitting next to her on the 14-hour flight, she comes from a Sikh Punjabi family. We‚Äôve had quite a lot to talk about on this flight from Hong Kong to Singapore ‚Äî school, work, mental health, politics, religion, travel, programming languages, how I fainted into Gabriel‚Äôs arms while I received a shot in the butt two days after our wedding, and so on. Look Mom, we‚Äôre socializing!

item.title: Counting down the hours‚Ä¶
item.description: Less than 24 hours to go for Arian and Karen until getting on the first plane! Preparing has been more difficult than expected. We‚Äôve moved before, but this time we need to decide for every item if we are giving away, selling, storing, or bringing with us. How much do we bring for a year? How much of our stuff do we really need to store? Selling off our house and cars is somewhat liberating, but trying to be sure we are bringing everything we need is a challenge. We can‚Äôt just Amazon Prime a forgotten item! On the other hand, there will be stores (it is the capitol city!), and maybe there will be some kind of internet delivery possible. We‚Äôll just have to see. It‚Äôs going to be a grand adventure!

item.title: December in Eswatini
item.description:
It seemed strange to be preparing for Christmas with the sun shining so warmly. To help get into the holiday spirit, Arian joined a small singing group. They lead Christmas caroling at a community center in town. The kids joined right in and a good time was had by all.

We also had the opportunity to attend a youth Christmas concert. The event was organized by a Taiwanese program that provides musical instruction to high-risk youth. They teach the children traditional Swazi dance, western choral music, and orchestral instruments. At the same time, they provide apprenticeships for local musicans who are interested in learning to be instructors. It was a lot of fun to see how much the program has accomplished in only two years!

The most exciting thing about December was knowing that we would soon be seeing Damian, Lilly, Gabriel, and Kendrea in Japan! We will be with them for two weeks. Definitely makes the year easier!

item.title: Family Christmas in Japan
item.description:
The last two weeks of December ended up being our first leave from Peace Corps. From the start, we wanted to visit Gabriel and Kendrea in Nepal, and Damian and Lilly in Japan. Unfortunately, it‚Äôs hard to get much leave in the first few months, plus the cost was horrendous, so we didn‚Äôt end up going to Nepal. Instead, we went to Japan with a bonus: Gabriel and Kendrea finished their study abroad and were going through Japan on their way home to Oregon! We were there for two weeks and stayed at Damian and Lilly‚Äôs apartment in Sanuma (in Tome).

We took a shuttle bus to Johannesburg so we could fly out of O.R. Tambo International Airport, then had a layover in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. We even made a quick stop in Seoul, Korea for reasons I still don‚Äôt understand, but necessitated everyone leaving, going through security screening again, then re-boarding. Definitely wasn‚Äôt some emergency thing since we did it both ways.

We landed in Narita and took a train to a guesthouse for the night. It was a great little place very close to a historic street. In the morning, we walked down the street, and got fire-roasted yams and chestnuts from different street vendors. We talked to Karen‚Äôs brother Dan and he highly recommended that we go to a close by temple complex, so we headed over there. It was quite beautiful and I‚Äôm glad we could go.

Getting back to the guesthouse, we met a guy named Ignacio who was from Belgium and was finishing up a year-long bike ride around the world! We chatted for a bit and got insanely jealous. He‚Äôs been to so many places and gotten to see so much. Places I wouldn‚Äôt normally think of as safe enough to visit, let alone to cycle through! You can read more about him on his blog.

Damian and Lilly met up with us in Tokyo and we spent two nights there. Tokyo is a great city! So many things to see. We took the train wherever we went (public transit can be so liberating!) and went to several areas. We also spent a number of hours at the Edo Museum. So many great exhibits showcasing the Edo period. I love miniature models/dioramas, and this place had so many!

We also went to the St. Nicholas cathedral (ok, so it‚Äôs actually called Holy Resurrection Cathedral) and were able to attend liturgy. It was so wonderful since there‚Äôs no Orthodox church in Eswatini. I couldn‚Äôt understand it, but I was able to follow along in an English-language book and sing along phonetically. Saint Nicholas and the cathedral are actually pretty big deals in Tokyo. Since there are so few Christians, the bells are a bit unusual and well-known. The Edo Museum even had a recording of the bells to accompany their model!

We went up to Damian and Lilly‚Äôs place and got settled in. The next day, we drove to Sendai Station (not as far as Tokyo) to pickup Gabriel and Kendrea. Now our group was the full six. It was such a wonderful feeling being around all of them after so long! That‚Äôs definitely the hardest part of being so far away.

During the visit, we played games, talked, and saw various sites in the region. We were consistently amazed with the number of vending machines out and about! Pretty much every block, you‚Äôd see one, two, six different machines. Mostly beverages, but it was very cool to see machines where the cans of hot drinks were actually hot! Coffee, cocoa, corn soup, all ready to go. It‚Äôs hard to imagine how they get enough business.

In case you couldn‚Äôt get enough from the machines, there were convenience stores (kombinis) every few blocks. One chain called Lawson, and then quite a few 7-11‚Äôs. Food was readily available and reasonably priced. The only real issues were reading the labels, and my stupid celiac gut. It turns out that the Japanese really love their soy sauce. No, I mean really. It was hard to find almost anything prepared that was safe. Thankfully, Lilly was able to check the ingredient lists, and I was also able to use my phone to translate. It was definitely disappointing to be restricted like that. We were fine buying our own supplies and cooking back at the apartment though.

During our stay we saw a number of different temples. They‚Äôre quite beautiful. We also saw a windmill! It was a gift from the Dutch and installed at Naganuma Futopia Park. They also had a very long slide with rollers for the surface. It was probably for kids, but it didn‚Äôt stop all of us from having great fun on it too!

Before we left, we saw the Toyoma Education Museum in Tome which portrays a typical Japanese elementary school in the late 1800‚Äôs with lots of interesting exhibits in former classrooms. The next morning, on our way to the station, we visited the town of Ishinomaki. This was a town very heavily hit during the tsunami a few years ago, losing many children and other people in the flooding. It was sad to see how much recovery there still was left, though it was clear there was also incredible progress.

Our last stop was in the touristy town of Matsushima. It was a beautiful place with ocean views and a gorgeous park. Due to the features of their bay, they were somewhat protected during the tsunami and sustained less damage.

With some difficulty, we said our good-byes at the station. It‚Äôs never easy. Kendrea was to have an internship interview the next morning, and she and Gabriel would be getting ready for their own departure back to the US. We took the Shinkansen (bullet train) to Tokyo. It went as fast as 140mph! Definitely a great way to travel, though the price was outrageous‚Ä¶

Now back home in Eswatini, safe and sound (and Gabriel/Kendrea also home, for real), it‚Äôs time to settle back in and get back to work. I‚Äôm so glad we were able to make the trip, but it was a difficult departure. We already can‚Äôt wait to see them all again!

item.title: First week of work!
item.description:
Hello again from Japan! Last week was my first week of work as an ALT at three elementary schools in Tome City. I visited my main school three times, and my secondary schools once each. This will be the normal schedule for me.

This first week was full mainly of introduction classes. I have the class period to introduce my students to me, to Oregon, and to my family.

I started most classes by talking and taking questions about Oregon. Kids were usually surprised that we have desert in Oregon, and they were excited to talk about it. Japan doesn‚Äôt have any areas that can be called a desert, so this is something they‚Äôve never really seen before. They were also generally surprised that there are wolves living in Oregon, because they were eradicated in Japan a while ago.

When I talked about my family and told everyone I was married they were impressed I think! If I told them to guess my age before telling them I was married they were pretty close to the mark, but if it was after I got ten years added to my age! I think this is because it is extremely uncommon for Japanese people to get married before 27 or 28. They were also always excited to hear about my family pets, Sara and Griffin!

Every day at school both the students and teachers eat kyushoku, or school lunch. Everyone eats the same food, and it‚Äôs usually very good food. Children serve each other their lunch in the classroom, with those serving changing regularly. I eat either in the teacher‚Äôs room or with one of the students‚Äô classes.

Adjusting to teaching has been a little difficult so far. Some of the teachers I work with don‚Äôt know any English beyond what they teach, which can make commutation difficult. They‚Äôre also very busy, making lesson planning very touch and go. So far things have been going well though! I‚Äôm looking forward to seeing the kids I work with grow as people and as English speakers.

item.title: Getting down to business
item.description:
This week is all about setting up our new apartment and going to work. We arrived at our new place on Monday after our swearing-in. We went over in a truck along with our belongings, accompanied by a truck with items supplied by the Peace Corps which included:

  • Blanket
  • Sheets and pillowcases
  • Pots and pans
  • Flatware, cutlery, cups/bowls/plates
  • Large basin and buckets
  • Gas cooking stove

For us, everything was doubled since we each get a set, but instead of two stoves, they increased the two-burner to a three. The list is tailored to volunteers in rural areas so not everything applies as much to us. The large basin is for bathing (!) and the buckets for hauling water. We really lucked out with our place since we have a full kitchen that included cups/bowls/plates, and a regular bathroom with shower (no need for baths in a basin!). The gas cooking stove is to use if electricity goes out, which it does from time to time, even in the city.

Our place is simple, but very nice. The living room and bedroom are one room, with a separate kitchen and bathroom. We have a small patio with a table and two chairs outside. The place is run as a B&B, so there is a laundry machine available and several small units for our family and friends to use when they visit (hint, hint!).

After moving in on Monday, we ran around to a number of stores on Tuesday to get supplies that we needed. There are quite a number of food, clothing, and general merchandise stores around us so we found most of what we needed. We feel like it‚Äôs going to work out nicely here.

This morning, we went in for our first day of work. We will be working in the offices of the Ministry of Health with the team working on their electronic medical records system. This involves gathering the requirements, creating a usable system, collecting the right data, and reporting on the indicators needed by eSwatini and the various international agencies. Their biggest priority is reducing HIV infection rates and improving treatment, but a good medical records system makes it easier to focus on a healthy population across a variety of indicators.

In one day, we met quite a few people, and will hopefully remember at least of few of their names! There are many subgroups in the department with many responsibilities. They are well-focused on what needs to be done, but right now it‚Äôs a long list. We are excited to get up to speed on their systems and processes so we can hopefully contribute soon!

item.title: Getting started!
item.description:
We landed at King Mswati III International airport. It was very nice, but amazingly quiet compared to the last few airports!

The airport had large photos of the king, the queen mother, and the prime minister.

Customs was quick and painless and we were on our way thanks to a ride in a comfortable van courtesy of the program director.

From the airport, we had over an hour‚Äôs drive to Manzini where we are staying. The entire drive we saw roads under construction and relatively low traffic. Along the road there were unfenced cows and goats, along with many vendor stalls with fruits, baskets, bowls, and roasted corn.

We‚Äôre finally here and ready to get started. ‚ÄúHere‚Äù is the campus of the Institute of Development Management, where Peace Corps has dorms and classrooms. Everyone is doubling up to reduce room count. Fortunately they let Karen and me be roomies!

We found out that we won‚Äôt get local sim cards until Monday. That means no data, SMS, etc. It would have been nice to know we‚Äôd have data blackout for the first two days!Our cohort consists of eight people, including us. Three of them are medical along with one in sociology, there to teach, one is a videographer shooting training and other videos, then there‚Äôs a programmer I‚Äôll be working with, plus Karen and me. One did regular Peace Corps years ago, the rest of us are green. No one is much more prepared for what to expect than we are.Today and tomorrow we have some brief orientation sessions. The pre-training lasts a week and starts Monday. During that time we‚Äôll be doing language and culture lessons, lots of PC rules and policies, and learning more about our positions. It looks to be a pretty busy time. We‚Äôll be trying out ‚Äúnormal‚Äù sleep schedules. We‚Äôll see how it goes!

item.title: Ginger
item.description:
Some people may know that Japan, and Asian countries in general, like their ginger. It‚Äôs used frequently in many different dishes and is popular in candy and drinks. Ginger also plays a particularly large role in sushi, where the reddish picked slices are eaten with pretty much any form of rice and fish.

Since ginger is so popular, and since I rather enjoy eating ginger, we thought it might be fun to try to make some of our own pickled ginger. The process isn‚Äôt that hard and makes some pretty yummy ginger!

The first step is peeling the ginger root. The skin is tough and fibery. Also, we don‚Äôt have a potato peeler or anything, so I had to use our knife to cut the skin off. Overall, this was the most time consuming and difficult step (it‚Äôs really not a hard process).

The next step is to cut the ginger into thin slices. There‚Äôs nothing precise about this step, we just want small pieces to make it easier to eat with stuff later. Our mandolin doesn‚Äôt have any settings for thickness, so our slices are thicker than you‚Äôd usually find at a restaurant.

Next we need to put the slices in a jar and prepare our pickling juice. Now I should mention that we‚Äôre not really pickling the ginger in the normal way. We‚Äôre going to do what‚Äôs called a quick pickle. The brine/juice is a mix of vinegar, water, sugar, salt, and spices such as anise if that‚Äôs your jam. We boiled the mixture with ginger sprouts, but they didn‚Äôt really give much flavor.

Once the mixture has been brought to a boil and left to simmer for a few min, the juice/brine is poured over the ginger and allowed to cook for a few min before sealing it and putting it in the fridge. Since this isn‚Äôt a real pickle, we don‚Äôt have to worry about gas build up in the jar ‚Äì the container can be sealed and the pickle will brine for a few days at minimum.

For those that don‚Äôt know, raw ginger is quite strong and fibery. The vinegar and sugar will help sweeten and subdue the strong ginger flavor as well as break down the fibers a bit. That said, it‚Äôs still very gingery and has lots of fibers, just not as bad as raw.

In the end, the ginger didn‚Äôt turn quite as red as I was expecting, but apparently that‚Äôs due to the age of the ginger, younger = more pink. Though 2 days is the minimum for good ginger this way, ours sat for 2 weeks and is much better for it! The flavor is very good, still stronger than most restaurant grade stuff, but I prefer strong ginger.

Random ginger facts from the internet, pickled ginger has slight anti-microbial properties which may help in the consumption of raw food (fish mostly). Also, the vibrant pink often seen in restaurant ginger is because they add food coloring!

item.title: Goodbye Nepal
item.description:
Greetings from 1:00 in the morning, somewhere over southeast Asia!

Time to catch you up on our final three weeks in Nepal.

We went on lots of little errands to prepare to leave. We enjoyed finding new parts of town. Gabriel really likes the traditional architecture, so here‚Äôs a representative door.

We don‚Äôt usually drink coffee, but we enjoyed studying at the Western-style coffee shop and expanding our coffee horizons. We sometimes even got the coveted stupa-view seats by the windows.

It turns out that Nepal has a holiday for eating grapefruit, so instead of our usual one-on-one language partner class, all the Nepali language partners cooked up a grapefruit dish for all of the students! It was a truly bizarre concoction, with grapefruit, milk (we had a special milk-free version), peanuts, chillies, mustard oil, sugar, sesame seeds, spices, and who knows what all else. We sat around in a circle on the stage at the monastery cafe to eat it.

Our host family had some shelves installed, so of course they called up the shelf bike dude.

We sang in the Boudha Community Chorale Christmas concert! It turned out to be quite the fancy affair. It took place at the monastery cafe, so we enjoyed a feast of fusion food afterward. It didn‚Äôt start out very auspiciously from our perspective‚Äìwe took an accidental midday nap that made us late and then two people had to help get Gabriel‚Äôs tie on‚Äìbut the singing part went well! The Boudha Community Chorale (mostly foreigners) hosted the concert; the British Model College Choir (all Nepali students) and the Kathmandu String Ensemble (all Nepali adults) also performed. The musical quality wasn‚Äôt up to the standards we‚Äôre used to in Corvallis, but it was still a pretty special experience to sing the Hallelujah Chorus at the top of our lungs with a large, diverse musical ensemble at a beautifully lit Buddhist outdoor cafe in Kathmandu.

Swing club wrapped up very well! Seven people, including us, participated in the final lesson. We taught our most advanced students tandem Charleston while Yuki gave beginner lessons to some newer folks. We danced, sang, and laughed to a playlist of holiday swing music.

We finished finals!! We worked really hard, and we think it paid off (no real-time grading like we‚Äôre used to back home, so we‚Äôll need to wait for final grades to come in). I began this semester assuming that I could use my pre-existing philosophy essay skills, but I finally accepted that this school requires a different frame of mind. For my final paper, instead of bringing in my own science-y perspective like I would for philosophy papers at OSU, I tried sticking very closely to traditional Tibetan sources (translated to English, of course). I enjoyed stretching myself in this way, and I think it‚Äôs more in line with what the instructors intended. Don‚Äôt think that we had too much fun, though. They were still finals. Much stress.

The weather has been warm and sunny. Here‚Äôs Yuki demonstrating that one can comfortably snuggle with dogs outside.

Our last few days in Nepal were pretty pleasant, too. The Himalayas came out to greet us on a clear day. We delivered thank-you notes, recycled lots of class papers, did last-minute shopping around the stupa, had a serendipitous dinner with our friend Tia, and even visited Ch√∂kyi Nyima Rinpoche. We listened as he had conversations with other visitors in Tibetan and Nepali. We only spoke with him briefly, but it was lovely to bask in his kind glow.

See you in Japan!

item.title: Hello world!
item.description: Welcome to the journal of Kulp travels! Stay up-to-date on where we are around the world and the good and bad things happening. We‚Äôll try to make new posts frequently to keep people informed and as a log of our own.

item.title: Home at Last
item.description:
We arrived in Corvallis a month and a half ago, and wow, it feels like a lot of time has passed.

Looking Back on Nepal

It would be nice if living in Nepal taught us the meaning of life. It‚Äôs not quite so straightforward, though. Here are the real results of our time abroad:

  • By living in a very different place, we simply learned more about how the world can function. It turns out that near-anarchy (no traffic laws, no sanitation laws, no zoning, etc.) can kinda work. We think that the West should have more Nepali-style buildings with flat roofs for hanging out on, clotheslines, solar water heating, no central heating or AC, etc. These buildings have a smaller environmental impact with minimal impact on comfort (in the right climate, anyway).
  • We have new confidence that we can figure out food/water safety, public transit, taxis, restaurants, etc. just about anywhere.
  • We‚Äôve had lots of time to learn about, talk about, and reflect on religions (mostly Buddhism). We‚Äôre happy to talk your ear off about it anytime.
  • We have an alarming amount of Kathmandu dust and pollution in our lungs. In general, our immune systems have been through a lot, possibly for the better.
  • Seeing suffering people and animals every day strongly reminded us to help others as much as possible.
  • We have very mixed feelings about future travel. On one hand, we love Oregon and we‚Äôve had enough of the hassles of traveling (not to mention the expense and environmental impact). On the other hand, we find ourselves absentmindedly looking up job openings in Estonia and Singapore.
  • While still in Nepal, as we were planning our travels to Japan, we expected that we would lightheartedly joke about the cultural transition. Nope, we had a genuinely difficult time adjusting to all the differences! We both caught ourselves nodding sideways (the Nepali way) on several occasions. We felt indignant that we had just gone through all this effort to learn a new language (Nepali), yet we still couldn‚Äôt understand the (Japanese) speech of the people around us. It was hard, but it also provided a convenient transition period to minimize culture shock in the States.
  • We stayed in Nepal for just the right amount of time. We thoroughly enjoyed having enough time to truly settle into Boudha, but Nepal doesn‚Äôt feel like home.
  • Similarly, we studied religion for just the right amount of time. It was really wonderful to be immersed in the monastery school and debate with nuns over lunch. At the same time, it feels good to study technology, math, and science again.
  • To generalize, we reaffirmed the importance of balance. In the past, we wished for more chances to explore the world and more time to think about topics like religion, philosophy, and anthropology; I missed learning languages. In Nepal, though, we missed family+friends, the coziness of crafting, our musical instruments, and tech+math+science. It‚Äôll be an ongoing challenge to give all of these priorities the attention they deserve.

Our New Living Arrangement

We really lucked out! Our university‚Äôs family housing has a waitlist over a year long and we made it to the top right on time. Additionally, there are a variety of sizes and costs to the units, and you have to take the one that‚Äôs available when you finish your wait. We got the perfect size and budget, and our particular unit was remodeled right before we moved in!

So now we have a nice one-bedroom apartment that‚Äôs about a 7-minute walk from the edge of campus, on a quiet street, with good internet, and all utilities included. We‚Äôre having a good time making the space our own (by cooking a lot of Nepali food, for example).

Unfortunately, Kendrea‚Äôs had to spend a lot of time out of the apartment. More on that after the pictures.

What We‚Äôre Up To

Gabriel

I have quite the set of classes compared to what we took in Nepal! I‚Äôm taking a full course load of computer science, physics, and (surprisingly) geography. Here‚Äôs a brief description of each:

  • Analysis of Algorithms: Basically the class so far has been, ‚Äúhere‚Äôs an impossible-sounding task. Solve it.‚Äù followed by confusion, then ideas, then a solution. Some people complain that this kind of work won‚Äôt be useful in industry, but I only really want a job where it would be‚Ä¶
  • Programming Language Fundamentals: Programming is telling a computer what to do. There are many different philosophies to accomplish this, and this class talks about the unique challenges in defining and evaluating the grammar and semantics of a language.
  • Energy Alternatives: A 7-person physics colloquium about the physical limits of classical and alternative energy sources. We talk about the benefits and drawbacks of coal, natural gas, hydro, wave, geothermal, wind, solar, nuclear, biomass, and many other sources of energy.
  • The Weird World of Quantum Mechanics: Another very small physics colloquium about the nature of reality at the smallest testable and verifiable scale. In contrast to most other physics classes, the only inclusion of math is to demonstrate relationships. The class is mostly theory and discussion. The same professor teaches colloquia other terms about the physics and philosophy of time and consciousness.
  • Geography of International Development and Globalization: Why are some countries rich and others poor? How have people tried to explain this in the past, and what did they get wrong? This class is about how the expansion of capitalism and colonialism left marks on the globalized world we‚Äôre in today. There‚Äôs also a lot of discussion of the effects of a growing population and shifting labor market. Each student picks a country to focus on throughout the term, so I picked Eswatini!

I‚Äôve been surviving the transition from monastery coursework alright, and I got used to having an apartment right by campus pretty quickly. My proximity has also facilitates extracurriculars like participation in security club.

I‚Äôm studying computer science with a focus on computer security. This term, through the security club, I‚Äôve joined a group of six other students to compete in the Pacific Rim Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition, in which you take on the task of running a mock company‚Äôs server infrastructure in the face of professional hackers‚Ä¶ who are way better at attacking than anyone is at defending. And they‚Äôre also scouts from big companies looking to hire. And you have to defend the network for two 8-hour blocks over a weekend. We did well in the qualifiers last week, and everyone is optimistic about our performance in Seattle coming up at the end of March.

Kendrea

I‚Äôm working at Galois! Surprise! Gabriel and I have been excited about Galois for a long time now. I received an internship offer while in Japan; as of February 2, I‚Äôve now finished two weeks of a ten-week internship. It‚Äôs a shame that I have to spend 3-5 days a week in Portland so soon after arriving in the States, but it‚Äôs worth it to hang out with a concentrated group of ridiculously kind and smart people. My goal is to sneakily convince them that Gabriel, as a fellow ridiculously kind and smart person, belongs there, too. I‚Äôve spent most of my work time so far studying up on functional programming (Scala), abstract algebra (category theory), and epistemology (Quine). I‚Äôm working with a philosopher at a tech company named after a mathematician‚ÄîI love that I usually can‚Äôt even tell if I‚Äôm doing philosophy, computer science, or math! Just today, I jumped in on a new project to consolidate models in an effort to identify interventions that would alleviate food insecurity in Ethiopia.

Thank you!

‚Ä¶for following along, listening to our stories, and supporting us!

item.title: Homestay: Here to Stay
item.description:
On Saturday, we OSU students packed up our things, checked out of Shechen Guest House, trekked in the heat to RYI (we really don‚Äôt recommend walking with rolling suitcases in Kathmandu), met our host families, and headed home with them for the first time!

Gabriel and I are staying in a three-story house in a fancy part of town with two brothers (Roshan and Milan) who work in the financial sector, their mother (Ranju), Milan‚Äôs 10-year-old son (Ishan), and at least one servant (Saili). Roshan is married, but his wife and son live in another house with his in-laws (and now Mesa from OSU!). The third floor consists of Roshan‚Äôs bedroom, our bedroom, a shared living room, a shared bathroom and a nifty two-level balcony. Roshan and Milan speak English pretty well, Grandma and Ishan speak a little, and Saili speaks none, but I‚Äôve bonded a lot with her just by smiling and gesturing.

The family members belong to the highest Hindu caste ‚Äî Brahmin ‚Äî so Gabriel and I, as outcastes, have to avoid ritually polluting them or their home with our presence. We stay out of the kitchen and shrine area. Menstruating women aren‚Äôt allowed in the kitchen. (Nepal is mostly Hindu, so it‚Äôs not a surprise that we‚Äôre staying with a Hindu family. We‚Äôre studying Buddhism, though, which does not have a caste system.)

Milan and Roshan have crazy busy work schedules, so we‚Äôve spent by far the most time with Grandma. Saili and Grandma serve us food and clear our dishes. It‚Äôs a constant struggle to insist that we‚Äôre full and don‚Äôt need any more food! Grandma sits with us as we eat. She used to teach Nepali language, so she has taken it upon herself to teach us a bunch! Between Nepali lessons during RYI orientation and informal lessons with Grandma, I estimate we‚Äôve learned 100 words so far. Not bad for three days.

The food is DELICIOUS. They cook nearly the same thing for lunch and dinner every single day: dal (lentil soup), bhat (rice), tarkari (vegetable curry), Nepali salad (just cucumber and carrot), and achar (various kinds of spicy pickles, analogous to salsa). It‚Äôs my favorite cuisine, so I don‚Äôt mind the repetition at all. Plus, you can imagine that you get really good at cooking something when you make it twice a day for decades! I really hope that Grandma or Saili will agree to give us cooking lessons sometime.

Side note: our intrepid guide Dr. Barstow went home to Oregon a week ago. It was great having him along, but we don‚Äôt mind the increased independence now that we have our feet under us!

item.title: Introduction
item.description:
We‚Äôre going to Nepal! And we‚Äôre blogging about it. We hope that the blog will help us keep in touch with friends and family, share what we learn, and remember the trip in future years.

We leave mid-August and return late December 2019. We‚Äôll live near Kathmandu (Nepal‚Äôs capital). Specifically, we‚Äôll stay with a host family in the town of Boudhanath, which has a rich Tibetan-influenced culture. (The Himalayan mountain range divides Nepal from the China-controlled Tibetan plateau.) We‚Äôll attend the Rangjung Yeshe Institute, an international school based at a Tibetan Buddhist monastery called Ka-Nying Shedrub Ling. We‚Äôll both take classes in Buddhist Philosophy and Hermeneutics, Anthropology of Nepalese Religion, and Nepali Language.

We owe this opportunity to Dr. Geoff Barstow from the School of History, Philosophy, and Religion at Oregon State University (OSU). Last fall, he visited my World Religions class to talk about this study abroad opportunity. I immediately got super excited, but didn‚Äôt have much hope that I could actually go. As a concession, I signed up for his course about Buddhist ethics in the spring. Then, we learned about the plans Lilly & Damian and Karen & Arian had for the year‚Ä¶ suddenly, moving halfway across the world ourselves seemed less ridiculous! Dr. Barstow turned out to be an outstanding and highly approachable professor, so we had plenty of chances to ask him questions about studying abroad. We‚Äôve met the other five students from OSU who will also go on this trip: Jesus (who was in my Buddhist ethics class), Kalie (whose best friend we know from Gabriel‚Äôs church), Yuki (who I helped with German pronunciation in choir last year), Yi-Hsiang (whose family lives near Tibet), and Mesa (who goes to OSU-Cascades in Bend, Oregon).

If you‚Äôd like a refresher at any time about who we are and what we‚Äôre talking about, see our biography and glossary on the ‚ÄúAbout Gabriel & Kendrea‚Äù page. Please keep in touch! For our part, we‚Äôll do our best to keep this interesting.

item.title: January in Eswatini
item.description:
One more week left of January. Nothing exciting since our return. We did get to go on a hike with some other volunteers to the top of Sibebe Rock, also called Execution Rock. It looks like a hill, but is actually the largest rock in the world (depending on who you ask‚Ä¶). It was some beautiful landscape with some trails through fields, grazing cattle, and even a lone horse!

We left way too early in the morning after waking up around 5am. I am not a morning person, so this was not an easy feat! We took a taxi to a starting point and just started walking the nearest path, hoping that it was the right away! We ended up walking through a homestead where we were given friendly help and they removed a section of their fence so we could walk through!

Part of the walk was along a rough road that was crazy narrow and steep in parts. I can‚Äôt imagine having to drive it! At one point, we saw some grass bundled together to be used on a thatch roof. It was pretty cool just seeing them lying there drying out. We also walked past a cave/alcove where a horse was hanging out. Unfortunately, I didn‚Äôt have my camera ready in time to get a shot of him still in there.

The hike ended up being several hours and was pretty tiring overall. Having started earlier, it wasn‚Äôt too hot until toward the end. I don‚Äôt think we could have done it much later!

We also walked past people working in their fields of corn and other crops. The area is on the outer edges of Mbabane so much more rural than we see day-to-day. It was so nice getting away for a few hours.

That‚Äôs really the only cool thing we‚Äôve done this month, but hopefully there will be more! The hot season is apparently going to be cooling off in the near future which will make it easier to enjoy the outdoors, at least until it gets cold! We still have several game preserves to go to that we can‚Äôt miss!

I‚Äôm grateful that we have a great group of fellow volunteers who enjoy doing fun things! Trying to find our way around can be daunting, so it‚Äôs nice to be able to go with volunteers who have knowledge of a place or better understanding of how to go places. Since we can‚Äôt drive (Peace Corps Eswatini rule), we generally know the area where we live. Having a larger group makes these fun adventures possible!

item.title: Kancane kancane (little by little)
item.description:
It‚Äôs been awhile since our last post. Any activity that relies on the internet is a challenge. This evening I need to study Siswati so I decided to go ahead and roll the blogging and the studying together. For once the internet connection seems to be holding steady.

Spring has arrived and we no longer need to wear layers of pajamas under layers of blankets at night.

Night = kuhlwile (The ‚Äúku‚Äù sounds like ‚Äúgoo‚Äù and the ‚Äúhl‚Äù is a cat hissing sound that you make by putting the tip of your tongue behind your teeth and letting air flow between your cheeks and tongue.)

Ulelenjani? = How did you sleep? Ngilele kahle = I slept well.

For the most part, the weather has been sunny and comfortable. Lilanga = sun (it also means day). We have had a few days that have gotten really hot (kuyashisa) followed by impressive thunderstorms (liyadvuma) and rain (imvula).

We get up early and make breakfast. I have been having porridge made from sorghum (emabele) with peaches (emampentjisi). Then we walk down the hill to work. A couple of industrious locals come by the office to sell boiled peanuts in the shell (ematongomane), boiled corn on the cob (umbile), and avocados (emakotapeni) around noon for everyone who forgot to pack a lunch. ‚ÄúEma‚Äù is a prefix indicating multiple of something so when you buy just one avocado it‚Äôs just likotapeni.

At work, we follow the guidance of our boss (mphatsi) so that we can better understand the needs of the citizens (nine bekunene) of Eswatini. We are staying very busy with the project. Ngimatasatasa = I am busy.

At the end of the day we either walk about two blocks to visit the mothers (bomake) who sell fruits and vegetables in the stalls along the street, go a little further to the shopping center for last minute dinner items, or just head back up the path to our apartment.

By this point in the day, I‚Äôm usually really hungry (ngilambile) and tired (ngidziniwe). There aren‚Äôt as many convenience foods here so we cook (pheka) every day (onkhe malanga) and always have a lot of dishes to wash. We also have to wash the produce carefully so our delicate American stomachs don‚Äôt end up in knots.

Sometimes in the evenings I study (ngifundza) Siswati, but usually I just drink tea (nginatsa litiya) and read for awhile until I am sleepy (ngiyatela).

Note: the word kancane from the title is pronounced with the ‚Äúc‚Äù as a click made by the tip of the tongue on the back of the front teeth. So it‚Äôs like gan-*click*-an-ay. The click is used is a lot of words, for example no (cha) and sorry (ncesi).

item.title: Kathmandu and Boudha Too
item.description:
The last three days have been a whirlwind!

We are now proud residents of Boudhanath (‚ÄúBOH-dah-nahth‚Äù), called Boudha (‚ÄúBOH-dah‚Äù) for short. We‚Äôd imagined it as a separate town, but it‚Äôs really just a district of Kathmandu, just as bustling as the rest of the city. Also, we mistakenly thought it would be like a culturally distinct Tibet-town. Sure, you see more Buddhist monks and Tibetan signs here than elsewhere, but it still blends into the Hindu Nepali rest of the city. According to Dr. Barstow, it‚Äôs difficult to distinguish between the two cultures at all ‚Äî Kathmandu has been a center of cultural exchange between India and Tibet for millennia.

Lemme try to paint a picture here. Narrow streets twist and turn around haphazardly constructed buildings. To navigate, you step over mud puddles, under low-hanging cables, and through gates. You‚Äôll see some construction zones, because the 2015 earthquake left lasting damage. It‚Äôs monsoon season, which means that it rains torrentially for a few hours each day, so you‚Äôll want to duck under concrete shop awnings for cover. Watch out for taxis, cars, and especially motorcycles! They‚Äôll speed around blind corners, honking to tell you to get out of the way. You‚Äôre bound to bump into some fellow pedestrians, but they‚Äôre used to it; no need to say ‚Äúexcuse me‚Äù. Several stories of tiny shops, each packed with goods, line the road. Most seem to specialize in one thing: fruit, soap, space heaters, you name it. My favorites so far are tailor shops ‚Äî they‚Äôll sew you whatever you like from the beautiful rainbows of fabric stacked from the floor to the ceiling. Boudha is centered around its famous stupa, one of the largest in the world. To show respect, always walk clockwise around it. In the touristy area around the stupa, you‚Äôll see Buddhist statues, Buddhist prayer beads, and souvenir T-shirts.

We hope to write specialized blog posts soon about food, animals, Rangjung Yeshe, local religion, and such. I‚Äôd like to remember the first things we did here, though, so here‚Äôs a quick chronological rundown of our first few days.

Day 1

We ate breakfast at Shechen Guest House with the group (plus a lovely Indian-Australian family we made friends with at the airport), then headed out right away to see Boudha for the first time. We spent an hour or two crowded into a closet-sized enclosure of ATM machines and walking back and forth between a photocopy shop and a Ncell (Nepali cell service) shop to get SIM cards. To get there, we had to cross the main road for the first time ‚Äî quite the exciting experience when there are practically no traffic laws! Then, we visited the Western-style coffee shop and went to my now-favorite restaurant for lunch. In the afternoon, we spent a few hours at someone‚Äôs home. Megan, a student who participated in this same program last year, is house-sitting there and taking care of the kitten, Rigpa. Dr. Barstow left so that Megan could tell us dirty secrets! (Spoiler: there are no dirty secrets unless you participate in the nightlife in the backpacker ghetto area of Kathmandu. Not our scene.) Finally, Megan, Mesa, Yuki, Gabriel, and I ate dinner at a Spanish restaurant with unimpressive food but an impressive view.

Day 2

Over breakfast at the guest house, Dr. Barstow proposed a relaxed itinerary for the day, but it quickly became apparent that his definition of ‚Äúrelaxed‚Äù is different from ours. We started by visiting our new school, Rangjung Yeshe. Unlike other monasteries tucked away into small spaces, this one has quite the large compound! We met one of Dr. Barstow‚Äôs close professor friends, the wonderfully caring student services coordinator (who Ch√∂kyi Nyima Rinpoche calls the ‚Äúshedrub mama‚Äù), some monks, and even an administrator from Corvallis. We went along with Dr. Barstow to the quarters of a senior monk to have him fill a couple Tibetan statues with religious items.

Next, we kept walking‚Ä¶

and walking‚Ä¶

and walking‚Ä¶

until we reached a more rural area.

We had some well-deserved sodas from a corner store at the top.

Worn out, we took taxis back to Boudha, recovered with a cold matcha latte and blended mocha at the Western coffee shop, rested at the hotel, went out to dinner, and picked up a few necessities (yay hand soap!) at one of the larger corner stores.

Day 3

Running out of time, so I‚Äôll keep this short! We went on our biggest expedition yesterday. We took a long taxi ride across Kathmandu to Swayambhu, one of the holiest sites in Newar Buddhism. Boudha felt pretty urban, but the larger streets and crowds in the middle of Kathmandu set it apart. Dodging street dogs, adorable monkeys, and less-adorable pushy street vendors, we walked up many flights of stairs, observing all kinds of ancient art along the way. The top of the temple has so much history and significance that I feel terrible devoting so few words to it, but you can read more here.

On our way back home, we stopped in Thamel, the backpacker ghetto area of town that Dr. Barstow can‚Äôt stand because of its extreme orientation toward foreigners. However, it has the best bookstores and restaurants, so we browsed his favorite bookstore in the world ‚Äî I bought two books ‚Äî and ate lunch at a large Western-style pizzeria.

Back in Boudha, we went to Fr. Greg‚Äôs home. He‚Äôs a Jesuit Catholic priest, longtime resident of Nepal, extremely knowledgeable anthropologist, American, and our academic advisor. I think he‚Äôs the first person we‚Äôve visited who has a servant. This particular servant, Raju, is a friendly dude and an incredible cook! Over tea, Fr. Greg told us all about the sprawling Nepali bureaucracy. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs legal to publicly criticize the government, so I‚Äôll stop there‚Ä¶

On the way home from dinner, Jesus, Gabriel, and I came across a large group of monks dancing in the dark at the Shechen monastery. It was mesmerizing. We sat and watched for a while.

Time for breakfast! Be back soon.

item.title: Life during pre-service training
item.description:
So it‚Äôs now Thursday. We‚Äôve been in training since Monday, but in eSwatini since Friday or so. It‚Äôs been pretty intense overall. Our days are planned from 7am until 7pm. Breakfast, then language, then tea time, then a lecture followed by lunch. A few more lectures, then an off block (‚Äúwellness‚Äù) followed by supper at 6. Outside of hours, we are restricted to campus. We can‚Äôt drive, and we aren‚Äôt all that comfortable with transit yet. The surrounding area (not really a neighborhood) has a number of street vendors, but it‚Äôs not really a place to wander around.

Today, we took our first trip on the local transportation, the khumbi (koom-bee), where we needed to communicate in SiSwati to find the right ride, learn the price, pay, get off at the right spot, etc. Our language teachers accompanied us so we wouldn‚Äôt be completely terrified!

These are very different from American buses! They drive past rather frequently and you need to hail them to stop, then make sure they are going where you want to go. There are places they tend to stop, but only the Swazis seem to understand where! You sit on a bench seat. It‚Äôs crowded, but only as much as there are seat belts. No standing since khumbis are really just passenger vans. Then the driver gets going to the destination. At some point, sometimes not until you get off, the conductor asks for the fare. The conductor accompanies the driver but sits with the passengers to answer questions, determine if there is space for another person, and handle money so the driver can drive. It‚Äôs all by hand, nothing electronic or computerized.

The ends of routes are usually the bus ranks. Think of a bus station, but then stop thinking of a bus station. It‚Äôs not really anything like that. A huge number of khumbis wait for people, their conductors calling out. It‚Äôs densely packed with people and vehicles trying to get where they need to be. Also lots of fruit and other vendors. Somehow it works out!

A word on language‚Ä¶ We understood that English was the official language so knowing the local language, SiSwati (a Zulu relative), was mostly for making a good impression. It turns out that SiSwati is still used quite a lot. People freely switch back and forth, and outside of offices, English is definitely second-class. It is true that, even in offices, being able to greet and introduce yourself in SiSwati is important.

Speaking of offices, we visited the official Peace Corps office in Mbabane today. It‚Äôs somehow part of the embassy, though a different building. Security to get in, phones left at the door, etc. Once inside though, it was a pleasant yard and a pretty normal office building. We went over some things and had another briefing. They take our safety and wellbeing very seriously so we talk about how it all works, our role, their role, etc. pretty often.

One more full day of training. We still have language Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday, but after tomorrow much less lecture and more traveling/sightseeing/shopping. I‚Äôm looking forward to finally seeing our actual residence in Mbabane. We‚Äôve met our counterparts at the Ministry of Health so we have an idea of how our project will go. We‚Äôre almost there!

item.title: Makhwapheni
item.description:
Makhwapheni (mock-wah-pay‚Äô-nee) ‚Äì Temporary lover

After working hard alongside the Swazis the past almost 8 months to assist with building up their medical records system, the plug has been pulled.

The journey has been hard at times. Coming as the latest in a line of various volunteers and other organizations, it‚Äôs hard to assure people that we are there to help and won‚Äôt just start some crazy new thing and then run off. Our focus has been to try to add features to their EMR (electronic medical records system) and update some of their processes to enable them to offer the care the population needs (by their invitation and working on their priorities). Coming from a different background, our experience includes things that haven‚Äôt been tried here so we worked to train/mentor local people so they would be able to utilize these techniques for the long haul. The Peace Corps‚Äô definition of success includes leaving an organization in a state that they don‚Äôt need you anymore. If we can‚Äôt leave without things falling apart, we‚Äôve failed.

Makhwapheni (from the post heading) apparently means ‚Äútemporary lover.‚Äù There are always (in every environment) people who are resistant to change, looking for a reason to discount new ideas. Makhwapheni implies that since we‚Äôre just the most recent in a string of ‚Äúlovers,‚Äù we don‚Äôt need to be taken seriously. This general idea also leads to questions about extending our time to get more done. At this point, we weren‚Äôt really interested in extending though since the goal was to pass along knowledge and perspective, then get back to family and friends. Now it‚Äôs out of our hands regardless and we can‚Äôt even finish our commitment. That‚Äôs really the worst possible case since we weren‚Äôt able to get things to the point of hand-off, and it basically validates their initial worries. It‚Äôs all kind of surreal at the moment.

We‚Äôll write another post soon with more details. At the moment we don‚Äôt have any more information to give. Volunteers are all waiting at their posts for further instructions, packing and reflecting. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

item.title: Manga ‚Äì „Åæ„Çì„Åå
item.description:
Those of my family and friends that know me well know that I‚Äôve always been an avid reader. Devouring all of the fantasy and sci-fi novels I could get my hands on from the age of ten, I‚Äôve built up quite a hefty collection of books that I now have to lug along wherever I move. Not content with the cold touch of an e-book, I‚Äôve always preferred to read physical copies of all of my favorite books. I‚Äôve read my first copy of Eragon, my all time favorite book, so many times I had to buy a second copy because the first is literally falling apart.

Noticeably absent from my voluminous collection, however, is even a single volume of manga. For those who are as yet unaware, manga is a Japanese style of graphic novel. Manga is a term that covers all ranges of fiction genres, and I‚Äôm sure some non fiction as well. I discovered manga in middle school while working as a library assistant, and I‚Äôve loved the medium ever since.

Like many graphic novels, a single series of manga can span anywhere from 2 volumes to 100. This is in part because manga are also serialized, meaning one chapter is released regularly and compiled into a volume later. The longest running manga will typically run around 300 chapters, though there are those that have topped 1000. In order to have the complete series of a manga, one would need to buy all the volumes, or all of the copies of the serialized version.

This is where tragedy strikes. In the United States, not only are manga difficult to find in English, let alone Japanese, but they‚Äôre also rather expensive. $4-8 a volume doesn‚Äôt sound like much until you need to buy 27 of them! When you can buy normal print books for $20 ish dollars new, why would you buy a used set of manga for more than $100? As such, I‚Äôve only ever owned 5 or 10 volumes of manga, and never a complete series.

Until now.

Incidentally, in Japan, manga are very common and used goods are rather cheap. Today, Damian and I decided to go by a used book store on a whim after dinner, just to see what was on offer. They were having an absolutely ridiculous sale, where all manga currently priced at ¬•50 ($0.50) were marked down to ¬•10. Yes, that‚Äôs right. Roughly equivalent to $0.10 per volume. %0.025 of the price of a single used volume in English in the States.

I went a bit nuts.

I did buy a few more normally priced volumes, around ¬•100, but this sale was targeted directly at me, and I embraced it. In total I bought 88 volumes of manga. The cost of all 88 volumes came out to be about $30, or ¬•3000. 88 volumes for $30. In the States, at the used price of $4 per volume, I would have spent $352.

I‚Äôm not sure how else to describe my current state of mind other than elated, but a picture is worth a thousand words, so I‚Äôll wrap this up with one. Now I just need to figure out how to get all of these home!
