item.description:
Today was my first day at school! Class hasn‚Äôt actually started yet for students, but teachers continue to go to school and do administrative work and the like through most of the summer break.

My main, or ‚Äúbase‚Äù, school is called Minamikata Elementary School (ÂçóÊñπÂ∞èÂ≠¶Ê†°). There are 16 teachers including office staff and administrators. There‚Äôs one teacher for each grade, 1-6, who teach all subjects. There are two teachers for special needs students. There‚Äôs also a school nurse and a teaching assistant.

Everyone at Minamikata was extremely welcoming and helpful the entire day. I spent the first hour or so chatting with the principal and vice principal and getting an introduction to the school.

I have my own desk in the teacher‚Äôs room. In Japanese schools, the teachers move from room to room and the students stay in one place. As such, all teachers have their desks in one office instead of having desks in each classroom. Teachers spend most of their time in this room when students are on break. There were some students at school today, but only for club activities.

Most of the teachers at my school don‚Äôt really speak English. My Japanese isn‚Äôt amazing right now, but I‚Äôm sure after even a couple of weeks it will improve quite a bit simply from necessity! Nonetheless, I had a good time talking with the teachers and both asking and answering questions. I also had the opportunity to prepare for class.

Finally, after I showed an interest in sitting in on the kanji classes taught in the school to improve my own Japanese, one of the teachers brought me copies for the workbooks the students use. She also was so kind as to check my work after I finished each section, which was fun for both of us.

Overall I had a good first day, and I‚Äôm looking forward to the coming year. I‚Äôll be posting photos once I‚Äôve confirmed what is and is not ok to post online with my principal.

item.title: On our way!
item.description:
After sleeping for two hours, we boarded the shuttle from Corvallis to the airport, then took the 8am flight to Atlanta. Now we‚Äôre laying over waiting for the trip to Johannesburg. Finishing the final tasks of packing our luggage, packing up the house, and general house cleaning seemed like it would never be done! Then, actually walking out for the last time (after 10:00), the doors locked behind us, I think we all felt it more than we thought we would. Ten years in a house is a long time, especially when it‚Äôs your home from middle/high school up to marriage (as kids and as parents of those kids). It‚Äôs not just a house, of course, it‚Äôs a home.

It was tough as parents needing to focus on our own departure to the exclusion of helping the boys with theirs. One the one hand, it‚Äôs good that we all depart so close, but it feels like we parents should be there to see the kids off first. We know they‚Äôll do great once they are there, but the lead-up can be stressful.

Now, we work on cramming a little more on SiSwati language learning. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôll be impressing anyone with our vocabulary, but we don‚Äôt want to be completely unprepared! The first two weeks consist of daily Peace Corps classes about the country, the people, the language, and hopefully our actual assignments! We‚Äôve already done a number of hours of videos and assignments about the organization and what it means to be part of it. We aren‚Äôt too worried. We trust that between Peace Corps and God, we‚Äôll be taken care of! One day at a time.

item.title: One-third down!
item.description:
As I type this, it‚Äôs Sunday evening. It‚Äôs been a sweltering hot last few days with temperatures up into the 90‚Äôs, with some areas (what they call the lowveld) over 100‚Ñâ! The next few days promise more heat until Wednesday when it suddenly drops a ridiculous 40¬∞. We are expecting some rough weather, likely hailstorms again. Just when we thought we were done with hail!

Since we started August 1*

Last week, we spent a few days at the Peace Corps training campus (actually local school that lets them use it) for Thanksgiving. Volunteers don‚Äôt often get together formally, other than sometimes for the swearing-in of new groups, so some of the time was mandatory. We had some talks about being effective, new or revised policies and procedures, and some peer sessions where people talked about their projects or lessons learned. On Thursday, we spent about half the day at the country director‚Äôs house. It was a beautiful home and there was an enormous spread of food! The whole time was great for reconnecting with people, making new friends, and strengthening ties.

In just over two weeks, we‚Äôll be going to Japan to meet Damian and Lilly, and a few days later, Gabriel and Kendrea will be arriving! G&K will be finished with their semester abroad and heading home. We‚Äôre so excited that we can all meet up in the same place! We‚Äôve been having weekly video calls, but it‚Äôs never the same. Often, the bandwidth here or in Nepal just isn‚Äôt conducive to a good connection.

This week should be a good one. We are preparing to put out our second software release, and drawing up plans for the post-JAD updates. It‚Äôs a lot of work, and no small amount of pressure to get things right. We are looking forward to the challenge though!

item.title: Orthodox Church in Japan ‚Äì Pt. 1
item.description:
This first post is going to be an introduction to the churches in our area. I think this will probably end up being a series of posts because there‚Äôs a lot to share. Keep an eye out for some more posts with more artists of the Church here covered.

It‚Äôs been about a month now and we‚Äôve finally managed to make it to all of the churches in the area. The first liturgy we went to was in Ishinomaki, which is a bit of a drive south of us but isn‚Äôt too bad. We tried to avoid toll ways and ended up taking a longer route than necessary as the road we thought had a toll ended up not, so it‚Äôs about a 25-30 min drive normally. For our first visits, we tried to arrive a bit early to give us a chance to meet some of the parishioners.

Father Luke (Á•ûÁà∂„ÅÆ„É´„Ç´ Áî∞Áïë ÈöÜÂπ≥) has been very understanding of our situation and his English is good enough to convey important information. He‚Äôs asked me to read hours in English before liturgy at most parishes, which was interesting. The singing is also interesting at an the parishes, it‚Äôs all from the heart, but also unison, slow, and on a collection of pitches. Everywhere has been thrilled to have some new singers.

On that note, Father has 5 churches in the surrounding area: Ishinomaki, Kurihara, Takashimizu, Sanuma, and a few more. They‚Äôre all within a 30 min drive from us, so nothing too terrible, and they all have very small congregations.

Ishinomaki ‚Äì Áü≥Â∑ª

The church in Ishinomaki has some interesting history attached to it. The original building is still standing but is not being used as the church building anymore because the state took control of it. It‚Äôs currently a museum and is the oldest standing Christian church in Japan. We‚Äôll go there at some point and take some pictures.

The size of the congregations here is quite different from what we get in the US. Many Japanese people, even to this day, do not have cars so most parishioners walk to church. Very often the only cars in the lot are Father‚Äôs and ours. As such, 5 people seems be a rough average with some parishes being much smaller and some being a bit bigger. Obviously Tokyo, Sendai, and the other large cities have larger congregations but they also have transit systems so‚Ä¶.

Sanuma (in Tome) ‚Äì ‰ΩêÊ≤º

On our first visit to Ishinomaki, we were told there was vigil at 10a in Sanuma (our town), which I planned on attending. Lilly was in Sendai for JET stuff, so I walked the 17 min to get there alone. Once there it quickly became clear that it was actually liturgy, so that was a fun realization. Since the congregation here was 2-3 people, Father had to lead the choir as well as do everything else. He refuses to allow me to serve because, ‚Äúno one ever serves at these parishes‚Äù.

This church was definitely the smallest I‚Äôve been to, but the building is still large enough to accommodate a decent number of people. It‚Äôs possible that the small turnout was because it was a weekday liturgy or because it was firing the week of Oban (a family holiday). The next Sunday liturgy here is the end of the month, so we‚Äôll see then.

There doesn‚Äôt seem to always be a meal afterward services. Some places have, others haven‚Äôt. Sanuma did have a meal afterwards, someone walked to the 7-11 nearby and grabbed box lunches for us, as well as mugicha (È∫¶Ëå∂), or roasted barley tea, and some desserts. I got to talk with Father for a bit and learned more about orthodoxy in Japan as well as more info on the other churches he serves.

Takashimizu (in Kurihara) ‚Äì È´òÊ∏ÖÊ∞¥

This church is smaller than Ishnomaki, but larger than ours in town. The building is still the only one we‚Äôve seen not purpose built to be a church: it was clearly a house at some point that was gutted and converted. That said, it‚Äôs still nice inside and is the only place with all tatami floors.

This church is nestled into a small village kinda in the mountains a bit, so the town itself was tiny. It also only has one emergency radio broadcast tower, which is apparently right next to the church, and they decided to test it as I was reading post-communion prayers.

Wakuya ‚Äì Ê∂åË∞∑

This is probably the largest church in Father‚Äôs area. You know it‚Äôs large because it has two readers and an alter server (his boy is too young without someone helping him). It‚Äôs also on a larger road and the doors of the church open right onto the sidewalk which probably helps.

After the service, we went over to the hall and had a meal. This meal was actually more of a potluck, there were pickles, a seafood salad with tiny fish, and some other things that parishioners brought. Afterwards Father led a choir practice for the congregation on tone 8 (what they would be singing in a few weeks when the next liturgy happened there).

Also, going back to our time in Tokyo. I did get to go visit Nikolaido (Holy Resurrection Cathedral), but considering the length of this post, I think I‚Äôll make another one to cover that. I also wasn‚Äôt able to make it to a service, so I‚Äôll have more to say later!

Also, I‚Äôll try to watch comments better, so if there‚Äôs anything people are curious about feel free to ask!

item.title: Orthodox Church in Japan ‚Äì Pt. 2
item.description:
On the 15th, we were invited, along with a lot of other people from the area, to the consecration of St. John the Forerunner in Nakanida. Unfortunately, this was the first consecration I‚Äôve been to, and my liturgical Japanese is‚Ä¶ lacking.

The building was pretty darn full when we arrived, there were probably about 100 people there. This event had been announced all over the area so we drove an hour and there were definitely people that came from farther. There was also the choir from Sendai which came to sing and we really appreciated them!

Concelebrating was His Eminence, Bishop Seraphim of Sendai, 5 priests from the area including our Father Luke, the protodeacon from Sendai, and a collection of alter servers (no subdeacons though).

There was a whole lot of stuff going on that neither Lilly nor I could understand, but there were several parts of the consecration service that we still managed to figure out! The first was when all of a sudden there was a lot of very loud banging from behind the alter, then the bishop opened the beautiful gates wearing an apron over his robes and you could see the wooden structure of the alter being assembled. I couldn‚Äôt quite get a picture of it since I didn‚Äôt know it was coming ‚òπÔ∏è

After the consecration was done, they launched into liturgy which was our first hierarchical service here. Things went pretty much as expected, though it was fun to see everything in Japanese with so many clergy. We‚Äôve definitely gotten used to small, intimate services during our time here.

Finally, agreed the service was done, everyone went outside and took a picture of everyone in front of the new church. After that, we ask headed over to a banquet at a nearby hotel where we were fed some pretty yummy food and listened to lots of speeches.

During the banquet we talked to some Russian ladies that were all excited to talk to the young Russian family that had showed up. Unfortunately for them, neither of us knows Russian, so they were a bit sad and surprised. One of them spoke English though and we talked for a bit. We made some friends from the Sendai area!

We also got to talk to a French dude who worked on the iconostasis. Apparently a Japanese-French dude started a carpentry shop after moving to Japan from France. He then attracted some French people that wanted to learn Japanese carpentry and they work mostly on shrines. When they heard there was an Orthodox church starting in town, they wanted to take the job. The guy said that it was a really fun job, that they all really enjoyed making the iconostasis, and that they hoped they would get the opportunity to work on Orthodox churches again in the future. He also said that they used many, many different kinds of Japanese woods to make iconostasis and that it was fun to weave Japanese culture and orthodoxy together.

item.title: Rangjung Yeshe Orientation
item.description:
For the last week we‚Äôve been attending various events at Rangjung Yeshe Institute orientation. I should prolly start with some background info about the school:

  • Rangjung Yeshe Institute (RYI) operates inside a Buddhist monastery.
  • The monastery is named ‚ÄúKa-Nying Shedrub Ling‚Äù, but most locals know it as ‚ÄúThe White Monastery‚Äù.
    • ‚ÄúKa-Nying‚Äù stands for Kagyu and Nyingma, which are two of the four major lineages of Tibetan Buddhism.
    • ‚ÄúShedrub‚Äù means monks can take classes there, kind of like seminary (more on this shortly).
  • The monastery is in Boudhanath, a Tibetan neighborhood of Kathmandu.
  • Kathmandu University (KU) and RYI work together to offer credit for classes at RYI. This agreement is how we get OSU credit.
  • RYI and KU operate on the semester schedule, so a full course load of 16 semester credits gets us 22.5 term credits back at home. This means we can drop a class while still keeping our credits per term above the scholarship threshold.

Scholastic work for monastics is done at a ‚Äúshedrub‚Äù (remember that that‚Äôs in the monastery name). We do classes at RYI, which gives Western-compatible credits (through KU) for Western- and shedrub-style classes. We will be taking one such shedrub-style class from a Khenpo, the monastic scholar equivalent of a doctorate.

Almost all the classes are taught in English; Khenpo classes have Tibetan instructors and therefore a translator, but some higher-level Khenpo classes don‚Äôt have translators!

Now for actual information about the orientation! There are around 40 of us newcomers, and we attended many information sessions about food/water safety, earthquake preparedness, who to talk to if we‚Äôre stressed, proper etiquette for monastery and academic settings, etc. We also took prep classes in either Nepali or Tibetan. We chose Nepali, since that‚Äôs what our host family speaks. Overall, RYI offers language courses in Nepali, classical Tibetan, colloquial Tibetan, and Sanskrit.

Our classmates are ridiculously diverse. We‚Äôve already made friends with people from Germany, Tibet, Finland, Argentina, Ecuador, Korea, Mexico, India, and Netherlands! Most people are around our age, but there are maybe 5 or 10 older people in their 40s-60s. There are also a few monks and nuns.

One very comforting thing about RYI is that you take off your shoes before entering classrooms, offices, or the library. There are shelves outside each door where you put your shoes. Also, many of the classrooms don‚Äôt have chairs, so you sit on the floor.

Many of the orientation lunches were provided at the monastery-owned Utpala Caf√©, a short walk from the part of campus with classes. Being part of a monastery that does outreach to help all sentient beings, it should be no surprise that their whole menu is at least vegetarian, and whatever isn‚Äôt vegan can be easily substituted.

After this four-day weekend, we will start classes for real on Monday. Here‚Äôs what we‚Äôll be taking:

  • We are both taking:
    • Buddhist Traditions: History and Culture 1
    • Buddhist Philosophy and Hermeneutics (taught by a Khenpo)
    • Nepali 1
  • Kendrea is taking Buddhist Ethics
  • Gabriel is taking Anthropological Study of Nepalese Religions (taught by Fr. Greg)

item.title: Reading Week and Dashain
item.description:
We‚Äôre wrapping up Reading Week, which is a week off of school that coincides with the 10-day celebration of the largest Hindu holiday: Dashain. As spelled in Nepali, is should be pronounced DAH-saii with the the ‚Äúii‚Äù pronounced nasally, but the ‚ÄúDashain‚Äù transliteration is pervasive. Nepalis (very confusingly) swap ‚Äús‚Äù and ‚Äúsh‚Äù all the time, and transliterating the nasal is often done by adding ‚Äú-n‚Äù or ‚Äú-ng‚Äù.

Even though the school is affiliated with a Buddhist monastery, we still get the week off; This is similar to Americans getting winter break, regardless of religion. There are some Hindus working and studying at the school, so it wouldn‚Äôt be fair to them! Plus the semester is long and we need a break; why not make the break and the holiday line up?

Dashain is the time of year for visiting family, feasting, swinging on bamboo swings, flying kites, worshiping, and offering animal sacrifices. For us, this means the businesses are closed, the transit is busy, there are occasional headless goats on the sidewalk, family members visit (we were never introduced), there are animal guts on the kitchen floor, and we get a blessing from our elder, the grandma of the house.

Technology Troubles

Kendrea and I had tech issues within what felt like 5 minutes. Her laptop wouldn‚Äôt turn on and my phone wouldn‚Äôt stop turning on (boot loop). Both without provocation.

For the laptop, she was only really missing a few weeks of notes, since they hadn‚Äôt synced in a while. We went to a repair place in a fancy part of Kathmandu, and it turns out there was a screen recall! If that‚Äôs the issue (and it seems to be), the repair is free. We just have to wait two weeks for the part to ship from Singapore‚Ä¶ Thankfully we had the opportunity to use a temporary workaround and get the screen working at the repair shop, so she synced her notes to her phone and we aren‚Äôt down any files.

My phone has had an odd issue for a while where the backup/recovery utility can‚Äôt decrypt it, but the normal boot process still works. I had shrugged this off after little pursuit, but now I think I shouldn‚Äôt have. While unable to boot the main system, I was still able to boot into the backup/recovery utility. From here I did a full backup to a flash drive and reinstalled the operating system. I took the opportunity to install something other than what I had before, though, so I can proudly say that the only smidgen of Google code I‚Äôm running is sandboxed and unprivileged; everything else is open source!

Anyway, because of the weird encryption issue, I‚Äôm not sure if I‚Äôll be able to actually access that backup. I haven‚Äôt put much effort in yet, but there‚Äôs a chance I lost everything. And by ‚Äúeverything‚Äù I really just mean mostly pictures. And by ‚Äúpictures‚Äù I really just mean mostly memes. So not a big loss.

Trekking to Nagi Gompa

From our front door, we took an 11-mile (horizontally measured) hike halfway up the nearest foothill (2300 ft. elevation gain) to a Buddhist nunnery, run by Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche, that we can see from our rooftop. It was exhausting, the views were great, the clean air was a nice break, and here are a bunch of pictures:

We trekked with three other people. Sameer led the trip; he‚Äôs an upperclassman from India who happens to be Kendrea‚Äôs peer advisor. We got to know Tia in swing club, choir, and class; she already professionally translates between Hindi and English, and she‚Äôs here to learn to translate Tibetan and Sanskrit. Yuki is another OSU study abroad student, and we‚Äôve really enjoyed getting to know her well here. Between the five of us, we used seven languages over the course of the trek: English, Hindi, Nepali, French, Japanese, Tibetan, and German. We spoke English and Hindi between us, and all the others with passersby.

As we hiked through the tangle of prayer flags, I wondered aloud how they get put up: ‚ÄúMaybe they tie a rock to the end and throw it. Or maybe they pay kids to climb the trees.‚Äù Naturally, we shortly came across a Tibetan family trying to hang up some prayer flags. They had tied a rock to the end and were trying to throw it. Then (as our Tibetan-speaking group members told us), they recruited a child to climb the tree, offering to pay him. We later joked about how I speak and whatever I say comes to be.

Near the top, we came across a crystal clear stream that crossed the path. We used our water filter (thank you Stig and family!) to refill the water bottle and couldn‚Äôt help but realize that this is exactly the advertised use-case: encountering a beautiful Himalayan stream while trekking and low on water and wishing that there was a way to drink it safely!

Helping Classmates

As the resident computer science students, we had no idea how useful our skills would be. For Khenpo class (the one taught in the traditional Tibetan monastic style), we need to memorize 15 verses, 10 of which (at random) we will need to recite for the test. To aid in the memorization process, I made a small terminal program in under 100 lines of C. After showing it to classmate, they wanted to use it! Knowing that a terminal-run program is hardly the most intuitive UI paradigm for this crowd, we set out to re-make it as a website. Another night or two later and the teacher forwarded the link to the class. Here it is, if you‚Äôre curious. Judging by the thankful emails, texts, and even in-person comments we‚Äôve received, all before classes have even started up again, it seems that the memorization tool has been helpful!

item.title: Seminar Break
item.description:
Written on December 1. We‚Äôve had some technical difficulties.

We just wrapped up a 12-day break from school to allow students to attend Ch√∂kyi Nyima Rinpoche‚Äôs seminar. Wow, what an amazing set of activities we had planned for the break! We were going to attend some of the seminar, participate in a tea ceremony at a Taiwanese restaurant by the stupa, go on a three-day getaway to a Himalayan village, attend a town hall for American citizens at the ambassador‚Äôs house, get all of our errands done‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶yeah, actually we got sick and stayed inside all day, except for brief excursions to the pharmacy to get decongestant and pain pills. Sigh. At least we had time to be productive (and not just in terms of mucus quantity).

We have a little news, though.

We‚Äôre back in choir! We‚Äôd quit because rehearsals were at an inconvenient time for us. Last Sunday, we taught swing class as usual, and both choir directors came. After class, they pulled us aside and basically said ‚Äúhey, uh, we had a rough rehearsal last week and we could really use your voices‚Äù. We couldn‚Äôt say no to that‚Äîwe can manage to attend just a couple inconveniently timed rehearsals. So, later that week, we bundled up, showed up to the dress rehearsal at the lovely monastery-run outdoor cafe where we usually eat lunch, grabbed some music binders, and sight-read our way through. It felt great to sing in a group again‚Äîplus, we got to skip the messy learning process!

We had a lovely Thanksgiving dinner with a couple dozen other Americans at Fr. Greg‚Äôs house. We‚Äôd planned to cook a green bean casserole (heavily accommodated to fit the ingredients available here), but then we noticed that the recipe said to bake the casserole. We have no oven. Okay, green bean stir-fry it was! To our pleasant surprise, almost every dish was vegan, so we feasted well. There were even deep-fried Oreos. We met some new people and had some great conversations.

Also, we managed to spend Saturday night in the nearby Himalayan village of Nagarkot! More on that later.

item.title: Sendai ‚Äì ‰ªôÂè∞, Part 1
item.description:
Sendai! We haven‚Äôt talked much about this city, but it‚Äôs definitely the center of Miyagi. Sendai has a population of a bit more than a million people. It‚Äôs where you go for anything more than the basics, especially if you‚Äôre like us and find it hard to find that little piece of home. Sendai is where the only Costco in Miyagi lives, along with multitudes of other shopping locations, and a variety of specially shops not found elsewhere. Good examples of this are yarn shops, which are only available in Sendai.

Our little trip to Sendai, a bit more than an hour from Tome if you‚Äôre flush enough to take the toll road, started with a visit to the cathedral, as it was a Sunday morning. After finishing church, we decided to go see if we could find lunch nearby, and stumbled into a series of shopping streets.

These avenues are basically like if an open air market grew up to be a shopping mall. There are entrances to the main streets periodically, and the streets are roofed with glass. Despite this it is very clear that you‚Äôre walking down a road between buildings, with those buildings frequently extending up past the glass canopy.

The shops filling the street vary from hole in the wall ramen places to high tier luxury brands like Rolex and Gucci. There were also konbini („Ç≥„É≥„Éì„Éã), Japanese convenience stores, about once a block. One of the more interesting places we stopped by was a cat Cafe. It wasn‚Äôt what we expected, but it was a memorable experience none the less. My advice to anyone interested in visiting cat cafes is to do your research ahead if time, and that‚Äôs all I‚Äôll say about it for now.

We also had lunch at a magical kind of restaurant, yakiniku (ÁÑºËÇâ)! Order plates of thinly sliced raw mean and cook it yourself for the freshest of restaurant experiences. Some of them even have all you can eat buffet setups. Definitely a satisfying experience.

After lunch we headed over to the Sendai museum of History, where we got to see some historical artifacts important to the area, along with many, many maps. Honestly the museum almost deserves it‚Äôs own post.

There were of course samurai artifacts, mainly related to Date Masamune, the much celebrated feudal Lord of Miyagi.

Seeing so many old artifacts and clothing from Edo era Japan really impressed upon us how small most Japanese people used to be. It was fun taking pictures with Damian for scale!

There was also a whole section of artifacts related to the voyage to Europe Date Masamune sent some of his samurai on. They sailed to Spain by way of Mexico in an attempt to open trade, with additional visits to the pope in Rome, but we‚Äôre unfortunately unsuccessful. Not long after Christianity was banned in Japan, so no further attempts were made.

There were also some related religious relics, as the voyage was guided by Spanish missionaries and Spain in the 1600s was very, very Catholic. They were very interesting to see!

The final leg of our trip was the Sendai Aquarium, but since this post is getting a bit long I‚Äôll leave that for another post!

item.title: Settling into the work routine
item.description:
We have been holding a number of meetings and working hard studying the source code for their systems while Karen is studying their business requirements and clinical environment. There is a large push to add some new features for HIV tracking so we need to ask a lot of questions and really understand what we‚Äôre doing!

As part of this acclimation, I‚Äôve been to see two clinics: one run by the Red Cross, the other by the Salvation Army. It was surprising to see a chapel in the same building as the Salvation Army clinic, but Swazis are much more comfortable with religion not just being confined to church buildings. They even start many meetings with a prayer. So far they have been a generally humble and unassuming people who are very friendly and open about their beliefs.

The clinics do standard vitals, immunizations, and exams, but they also proactively do HIV testing on everyone they can in other to get people in treatment and educate them on how to live with or avoid it. They have done a great job of reducing new infections through awareness campaigns and talking frankly about the risks of sexual activity. It‚Äôs been quite successful, but they continue to do everything they can to eradicate it.

Each clinic has it‚Äôs own challenges with power and network connectivity. The systems deployed need to be resilient in addition to user-friendly and feature-packed.

In our workplace, I sit in a shared office with another Peace Corps volunteer (Noah), a business analyst, and a empty desk people float to. Karen sits in a similar office with data management folks. Noah and I also have desks at the office for the international consulting firm FEI across the street. We go back and forth working with various people.

We‚Äôve gotten our SiSwati names given to us by our officemates! Since my name means ‚Äúsilver‚Äùin Welsh, I‚Äôm Ngcebo (the‚Äùc‚Äù is a click) which means precious (as in metal). Karen is Buhle which means beautiful lady!

Due to where we live, we can walk to work in about ten minutes but don‚Äôt actually pass many businesses. The building where we work houses a number of other government and NGO offices but not much commerce.

On our way home, we pass a guy who sells roasted corn most days. It‚Äôs shucked and fire roasted which gives it a great flavor, though it‚Äôs much chewier than I‚Äôm used to corn being. The guy who sells it always gives us a big smile when we pass by.

As we turn to head up the very steep hill towards our place, there is an alcove at the base with carvings/sculptings of famous people. I believe it‚Äôs currently Nelson Mandela, Bob Marley, and their current ruler King Mswati III. It‚Äôs an interesting medium. He also makes dog houses and a few other items.

This morning (Saturday), we meet with another volunteer who has been working with Swazis running a program to introduce girls to STEM. Many of the rural schools don‚Äôt have any computers so the kids don‚Äôt even have mouse skills. The program starts with beginner computer concepts (turning it on, typing, mouse, windows, files) moves on to Microsoft Office, and even offers a game development class. Certificates are given for completion, and the kids work on a resume to showcase their new skills. Karen, Noah, and I are excited about helping where we can!

item.title: Shopping and culture
item.description:
Today was a pretty slow day. After breakfast, we meet with the medical officers to go over anything they need to know for our stay. Of course, everything should be in our record, but data doesn‚Äôt necessarily seem to follow us as it should. At least it was painless enough.After that, we took a bus to a shopping area. This was important to get a feel for what‚Äôs available here and determine how hard it‚Äôs going to be to manage diet. It turns out, it probably some be very difficult. Selection of food was great and prices were reasonable. From peanut butter to burritos, spices to snacks, deodorant to soap, we‚Äôll be able to get what we need.

After our shopping trip, we went to a cultural village. This is setup like a traditional Swazi village from over 100 years ago. The village is actually the domain of one guy, along with his mother, his wives, his children, and dogs and cattle. Each hut is a bedroom, a brewing room, or other gathering room. A friendly guide showed us around and gave us the details.

After the tour, we got to see a traditional dance as would have been performed by the single men and women. Their singing was amazing and the dancing quite lively. Not much relation to ballroom dance‚Ä¶

After that was done, we got back in our van. Right before getting in though, we saw a monkey nearby. It wasn‚Äôt the first, but it was the closest.

Back on campus, it‚Äôs rest and supper. Tomorrow starts the real work with our one-week training. No matter how challenging it is though, we can‚Äôt really complain. Regular Peace Corps pre-service training (PST) is three months!

item.title: Singapore to Kathmandu
item.description:
So first, there‚Äôs the Singapore airport. Stunning. Beautiful. Clean. You may have seen pictures of it before, but the largest indoor waterfall is inside a giant indoor rainforest in a glass dome. There‚Äôs also a walk-in butterfly garden and a koi pond. It‚Äôs just crazy.

We had about 6¬Ω hours between flights, so we (me, Kendrea, Mesa, Kalie, Dr. Barstow) decided to leave the airport! Immigration and customs was fairly quick, but there was definitely an authoritarian vibe‚Ä¶

We took a taxi to the famous Gardens by the Bay and saw the weird Marina Bay Sands towers. Entrance to the Gardens is free, but you need to pay to enter some portions. It was too much money to enter the indoor greenhouses, but we did decide to do the hanging bridge in the Supertree Grove.

After marveling at the cleanliness of the Gardens, we took the subway to Raffles Hotel. The whole subway experience was much closer to an airport tram than a US public transit vibe. We were shocked when we saw a single q-tip on the ground, since it was the only hint of litter. We ate some very good and cheap food at an underground food court, then headed up to Raffles.

We tried to go to the Long Bar to try a Singapore Sling (exclusive mixed drink), but the line was too long for how much layover we had left. Instead we went to a courtyard with a less-fancy bar and got some drinks there.

We walked a bit to find a taxi and returned to the airport. Everything went smoothly as we re-entered the airport, boarded the plane to Kathmandu, and left the ground one last time.

Kathmandu

We landed at around 9pm local time and exited the plane straight to the tarmac. A bus came to pick us up and bring us to the terminal, where we filled out a form on a glitchy kiosk, paid the $125 visa fee, and went through customs (which was kind of a joke). It took us a while to all make it through the process, but when we finished, we got on a taxi and had the strangest transit experience yet. Kendrea made the mistake of using the bathroom in the airport.

When we all reconvened after customs, we got on a taxi and had the strangest transit experience yet.

Many of the roads here are dirt and not exactly flat. There are usually no lines on the road. You don‚Äôt need a license to drive. Most people don‚Äôt wear seatbelts, and some cars (like the taxi) have them inaccessible under the aftermarket seats. Over half of the vehicles are motorcycles. Many of the cars are manuals with small tires (so you feel the bumps more). There are dogs, people, and sometimes even goats and cows in the road. Instead of slowing down before going around a blind corner, people just honk to announce their presence. If someone is driving too slowly, they‚Äôll get honked at when overtaken. It‚Äôs common to swerve into oncoming traffic to go around someone who‚Äôs slow, a sleeping dog, or a pothole.

Basically, the whole thing physically felt like a rollercoaster and emotionally was just a big game of trust. A taxi driver, of all people, should be pretty good at navigating the chaos, right?

We arrived at Shechen Guest House (where we‚Äôll stay until we move in with our host families) after closing time, so we had to kind of holler at the gate for someone to come. We entered a courtyard and picked up our key, then went to our room.

We found two pretty normal-looking beds that turned out to not have normal mattresses. They‚Äôre basically mats rolled out on the bed frame, so they‚Äôre pretty firm. Comfy enough, but certainly not what we‚Äôre used to in the US. We took a cold shower and went to sleep.

(Sorry for the lack of Kathmandu pictures. It was dark and we were very tired. More pictures to come later!)

item.title: Super Typhoon Hagibis
item.description:
For those that follow the news, you might have heard of the typhoon that slammed into Japan last weekend. The typhoon caused massive damage to certain parts of the country, killed a number of people, and caused flooding that lasted for quite a while. Thankfully, by the time the typhoon got to us, it had lost some of it‚Äôs oomph and we just got lots of rain.

The original predicted path for the Super Typhoon Hagibis had it hitting Tokyo and then sort of bouncing off and going back out to sea. That obviously didn‚Äôt happen though, and instead it hit Tokyo, went up the mainland, and back out to sea after hitting Hokkaido to the north. Though the path wasn‚Äôt what people were expecting, we still didn‚Äôt get hit very hard and only had minor flooding for a day or two.

That said‚Ä¶ people were definitely scared and we didn‚Äôt know what to expect. We kept getting emergency texts and emergency broadcast announcements (over loudspeakers) warning us that the conditions had gotten worse and that various nearby towns were either evacuating or opening shelters due to flooding. Not to mention that we live about 3 blocks from the river, so if the levees hadn‚Äôt held or hadn‚Äôt been high enough, we would have been in a world of hurt.

We did pack go backs and made sure to have some food, water, and clothing, as well as some books and stuff just in case we got the alert to evacuate, but it never came to that. As it started raining harder and harder, we walked down our covered stairs a few times and ran across the street to watch the water level rising. It was pretty incredible how quickly the water level rose in our little stream.

When we decided to go to sleep for the night, it was a little concerning again because not all of our windows seal completely and though the wind wasn‚Äôt as bad as it could be, it was still stronger than it had been during our time here. We did see some water in the tracks of two of our windows in the evening, but by morning everything was still dry inside. Also, our screens blew around and made some noise, but again, nothing was damaged in the morning.

Finally, we emerged on Sunday morning after almost 12 hours of heavy rainfall. Our side of the river didn‚Äôt have much for flooding, we have more fields mixed in to the city to absorb water, but the other side didn‚Äôt fare as well. The river near us rose maybe 3-4 meters (3-4 yards) and Sanuma had lots of roads that were under about 8 cm (2-3 in) of water, though that didn‚Äôt stop traffic from continuing on through like normal.

Church was cancelled in the town it was supposed to be in last weekend and was instead held in Ishinomaki. We weren‚Äôt sure we‚Äôd be able to make it since there are lots of sections that go through fields and we didn‚Äôt know how flooded it would be. Also, Google didn‚Äôt do a good job of staying up-to-date with road closures due to flooding, so we really had no idea if we could make it. As such we just stayed in our area and took pictures to show you guys, our awesome readers!

item.title: Swazi Fire!
Thanksgiving
item.description:
Well, it‚Äôs a bit late. Sorry about that! We had tons of prep beforehand and cleanup after!

First off, Thanksgiving is not celebrated in Japan, surprise! Though some American holidays have been adopted a little, Thanksgiving is definitely not one of them. So to celebrate it, we invited the Alt‚Äôs and a few of the Japanese people that hang out with the Alt‚Äôs.

In total, we had 7 people come over (we invited more but several people backed out day of‚Ä¶). We structured the meal part as a potluck, we provided the turkey, mashed potatoes, and pies, and asked everyone else to bring sides and drinks. People brought gy≈çza, mac and cheese, camel corn, and a variety of other favorites.

While we were waiting for people to arrive, we had Lilly‚Äôs switch set up for people to play Mario kart, which people seemed to enjoy. We also just hung out and talked a bunch. No football though! We don‚Äôt even own a TV!

Turkey

We did end up finding turkey at Costco in Sendai, so I got to defrost, prepare, cook, and serve a turkey for the first time. It was an interesting process, especially because the bird only just barely fit both in our fridge and later in our oven. Everyone seemed to enjoy it so it was worth it!

Desserts

Lilly wanted to make two desserts: apple cobbler and pumpkin pie. Cobbler is pretty easy and she‚Äôs made some very yummy cobbler several times before. As expected, the cobbler was delicious!

The more challenging dessert was the pumpkin pie. Usually pumpkin pie isn‚Äôt too challenging as long as you can make a good crust, but we faced a different challenge here: no pumpkins‚Ä¶.

Weeelllll, I guess that‚Äôs not quite fair to say. Japan has, ‚Äúpumpkins‚Äù in that they have a squash they call pumpkin, but it‚Äôs not.

The problem with Japanese pumpkin is that it simultaneously has less sugar and water but more starch than what we‚Äôre used to in the States. This means that pretty much no recipe will work as the ratios are all wrong. We had to try several different variations of different recipes before we finally found something that works.

I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôll mean much to people to give a complete recipe, but the biggest changes we made were as follows: add more sugar, boil the squash like mashed potatoes to get as much liquid as possible, and food process it a decent bit to smooth everything out.

Everything Else

The night went very well! People had fun, the food was all good, we enjoyed the company ‚Äì overall a good night! The mashed potatoes and mac and cheese were well received as American classics, and since most of the Alt‚Äôs don‚Äôt cook so they‚Äôve missed out!

item.title: The beach!
item.description:
So Lilly and I have been fairly busy, but I‚Äôll put together a few blog posts now.

Last week we went to the beach in Minamisanriku, an area hit pretty hard in the tsunami in 2011. In fact, the beach only reopened for public use last year. It‚Äôs a pretty nice little town though and the beach was very nice.

There were a few food stalls setup on one end of the beach, so we got snacks there first before going swimming. We went with a few other ALTs as we didn‚Äôt have our car yet, so we had to wait around a bit while the others tried to find us. Once we had all arrived we sunscreened up and jumped in the water.

The beach was pretty warm and the water was refreshing, not warm but definitely not cold. It was apparently Lilly‚Äôs first time swimming in a non-hypothermia inducing ocean, so she got to learn about mouthfuls of salt water and the like. For those not in Oregon, we have beaches but they‚Äôre very cold.

After we swam for a while, we decided to make a sand castle while we waited for some late arrivers to make it. The kids on the beach seemed to think it was pretty funny watching a bunch of adult foreigners trying to build a sandcastle too close to the water. After we finished building it, we decided to try and keep it alive until the others joined us, so we had to build large walls to protect it from the incoming tide.

One the last few people arrived, we did a tad more swimming and eating before heading over to a shrine that was attached to an island from the end of the beach. The hike was fairly steep but not too long or muddy despite recent rain. The shrine was neat but rather small and plain. The small island was hit pretty hard in the tsunami as well.

Afterwards we did a bit more swimming before heading over to a small market nearby. Some shops were closed because last week was Oban (a weeklong festival), but we did grab some stuff from a cute bakery. After that we headed to a coffee shop in Tome that the ALTs really like before heading home for the day.

item.title: The halfway point
item.description:
It‚Äôs strange how the pace of life is notoriously slower here and yet for us it feels like there‚Äôs a mountain of work and never enough hours in the day. Some of that can be attributed to necessary daily rituals such as cooking, washing dishes, hanging laundry out on the line. There‚Äôs very little prepackaged convenience foods so meals require more food prep. We are so lucky that we live close to the central shopping area of Mbabane, but it still takes longer to walk to the stores and back than it would to do it by car (not to mention that we have to carry all of those groceries up the hill!). I don‚Äôt mind the chores though since they seem like a natural and essential part of the daily life. The more difficult part is the office work. There‚Äôs a constant level of frustration because the ‚Äúright way‚Äù of doing things is often completely impractical here. You will have a time sensitive email that needs to be sent ASAP, but the internet is down (or the power is out). Last week we had a flash flood. I couldn‚Äôt cross the road to get to a meeting in the building right across the street because the road had turned into white water rapids! Funding is always on the verge of being pulled away from the project and the cut backs are crippling our efforts. There‚Äôs never enough hands to make the work light. Despite these challenges, our coworkers are excited about the direction of the project. It may not happen quickly, but progress is being made.

It‚Äôs also amazing how long six months can feel. I really can‚Äôt focus on the total time remaining because it seems unbearable to be away from family and friends for so long. But, one more day seems manageable. So, I am taking it one day at a time!

item.title: Tihar, Midterms, and Cooking
item.description:
The title is roughly in order, but midterms spanned several weeks across our classes, so that makes midterms actually overlap Tihar and cooking.

Anyway, first was Tihar! Nobody seems to know the origins of the word, but Tihar in Nepal is equivalent to Deepawali or Diwali, the Festival of Lights, celebrated across South Asia. It‚Äôs five days long, with specific times to worship/recognize crows, dogs, cows, oxen, the goddess of wealth, and brothers.

Being the Festival of Lights, nearly everyone displays brightly colored lights, often more than what you‚Äôd see during Christmas in the States. It‚Äôs inherently hard to take pictures of, but all the big businesses had 50+ foot-long string lights hanging from the roof down the walls. Additionally, this is the main holiday for fireworks. Compared to American Independence Day, Tihar involves many more firecrackers, and many fewer mortars, fountains, smoke bombs, and sparklers. That along with amplified music late into the night made it hard to sleep!

On the day for crow worship, people put food out for the birds. For the days for dogs, cows, and oxen, those animals get tikka (red forehead dot), good food, and marigold necklaces. For Laxmi, the goddess of wealth, everyone makes a sand mandala on the street outside their house or shop, with a line going inside. This is a greeting to invite the goddess in. For brother worship, sisters put tikka on their brothers. For some reason, we received tikka from our host grandma, and instead of just the red, it was a full rainbow! We also received a gift tray with nuts and fruits.

Over the course of the holiday, we lit fireworks and rockets on the roof, played cards, danced, and took a drive around the city to tour the lights, all with our host family! It was the most interaction we‚Äôve had since our first day at this house.

Next topic: midterms. It‚Äôs important to note that the classes here are far from what I‚Äôm used to. Computer science lectures, homework, and exams have little in common with anthropology, Nepali language, and analysis of Buddhist texts. We‚Äôve had to do much more memorization than we‚Äôre used to, but it‚Äôs working out pretty well so far! Many topics are organized in lists, so we need to memorize the content and order of the ‚Äúeight branches of this‚Äù and the ‚Äútwelve links of that‚Äù and the ‚Äúfour types of that other thing‚Äù on topics ranging from types of refuge to the physical requirements to generate the supreme virtue (bodhicitta).

Anyway, midterms went well overall. We haven‚Äôt gotten all of our scores back yet, but it‚Äôs pretty easy to gauge performance yourself with these things; you either know it or you don‚Äôt, and if the test asks what you know, you‚Äôre good.

Finally, cooking! Living with a modern Brahmin family these days usually wouldn‚Äôt mean much, but our host grandma is on the traditional side of things. As we mentioned earlier, we weren‚Äôt allowed to cook. However, apparently our homestay coordinator spoke with our host family recently, and they concluded that it‚Äôs okay for us to venture into the kitchen every once in a while. We are very confused about how this change of policy came to be, but we aren‚Äôt complaining. Today, for the first time ever (in Nepal), we cooked our own meal in our own home! It was just a simple stir fry, but navigating someone else‚Äôs kitchen is an order of magnitude more difficult when you don‚Äôt even know what utensils are normal to have!

This isn‚Äôt the first time cooking in Nepal, though. First, we ‚Äúcooked‚Äù a ‚Äúmeal‚Äù at a friend‚Äôs apartment that ended up much less organized than we expected. For the second cooking experience, we made momos (Nepali dumplings filled with cabbage+onion+parsnip+soy+garlic+ginger and dipped in spicy tomato-sesame sauce) at another friend‚Äôs house. Since that second friend lives in a homestay of her own, that was the first Brahmin kitchen we used. The momo-making process was quite labor-intensive, but well worth it for the delicious result!

Concluding thoughts, in no particular order:

We‚Äôre over halfway done!

It‚Äôs November and still short-sleeve weather. It was actually almost too warm today. We found an article about someone complaining about climate change and Nepal‚Äôs ‚Äúnever-ending summer‚Äù.

Now that it‚Äôs stopped raining with the end of the monsoon season, there‚Äôs nothing to keep the dust out of the air. It just blows around and gets in your eyes and lungs. We have face masks, but they can only help so much.

While shopping for ingredients, the only tofu we found was unwrapped and sitting in a tub of water‚Ä¶ very questionable sanitation. We cooked and ate it anyway. We‚Äôll let you know if we die.

We finally took a walk around the oasis of wealth that is the 5-star hotel Hyatt Regency Kathmandu! It‚Äôs only a fifth of a mile from our house, but it‚Äôs walled off, so we hadn‚Äôt found a way in before. This time, we went with a friend who has a swimming membership and can therefore get past the guards. We had fun breathing the fresh air among the plants, gazing at the lavish lobby, walking on the jogging track, seeing the pool, and *ahem* playing on the playground.

As of October 22, Kendrea is reunited with her laptop! The repair was covered by a recall, so we didn‚Äôt have to pay anything. She is greatly enjoying the brand-new display.

We can‚Äôt repair the wifi, though, so for those of us in Eswatini and Nepal, uploading pictures takes practically as long as writing the actual blog post. We hope you appreciate them!

We saw the Himalayas from our rooftop! We thought they were out of view behind the foothills, but it turns out we can get a peek when the clouds, pollution, and dust are out of the way at the same time.

In preparation for the trip, Lilly found a good AirBNB house that was a bit on the outskirts of Tokyo but still had train access. item.title: Umhlanga (Reed Festival)
item.description:
Last Monday we went to one of the biggest (or maybe the biggest?) celebration in eSwatini: Umhlanga, that is, the Reed Festival. Young maidens march from their villages to collect reeds which they then take to the Queen Mother‚Äôs palace to be used to build up the outer wall. They march 30km (10km for the younger ones) in regiments often while singing, then camping out for during the nights. The explanation is that the festival will encourage them to remain sexually inactive, show reverence for the queen, and build solidarity. The entire ceremony is 8 days with the girls marching, cutting the reeds, presenting them to the queen, and preparing for days 6 and 7 where they dance. On day 7 they dance at an arena within the royal compound with spectators and the king present. On the 8th day the king commands cows to be slaughtered and the girls receive a portion of the meat and head back home.

The stress on the virginal aspect of it (in modern days) relates to their efforts to reduce the transmission of HIV. They also encourage men to be celibate. Their rate of infection is the highest in the world and they are working very hard to bring that down. There is already a measurable improvement in their new infection rate.

Karen and I took a khumbi from Mbabane to the event, a trip of about 40 minutes or so. On the way, we chatted a little with a guy sitting next to me. It turns out he‚Äôs from Rwanda and he was very helpful knowing when to get off, where to go, and what was happening!

From the khumbi stop at the dead end of a dirt road, we starting walking down a path that quickly opened up into another road. Along the road were dilapidated houses and shops, litter, and an inexplicable stream of water running down the center. Despite its humble look, we felt safe and only experienced friendliness or indifference from the residents. We were among many other people heading to the royal residence. It was a bit striking how close this area was with such contrast.

We spotted an untethered cow, and then a chicken as we walked. Both ignored us. I don‚Äôt think anyone tethers their chickens.

We walked past a large number of shops selling clothing and housewares, along with small food stands selling various grilled meats, french fries (or chips as they say in UK fashion), and fruits and vegetables. We walked a decent distance not having any idea what we were looking for exactly or when we would arrive.

At some point we heard the sound of many people. We turned around to see a large number of people coming toward us ‚Äî the first group! As they got closer, we could hear that they were singing. It continues to amaze us how wonderful the singing in eSwatini is. This was no exception.

Girls were divided into groups of 8-13 year olds and 14-22 year olds. Regiments each had their own uniforms and song that they sang. I can only imagine that there must have been months of preparation leading up to the event.

Most of the girls had on garments that went around their waists and often shoulders or arms. It was a minimum of clothing which probably felt good in the hot sun. There is much pride in the outfits, and the topless nature of it looks from the outside to be evidence of positive body image, and a sense of empowerment. This isn‚Äôt about being sexually alluring ‚Äî it‚Äôs about them being themselves and embracing their femininity.

Once at the arena, the girls marched around the field, in front of the spectators, then to the back where they stayed. Groups sang and danced as they walked past. The field got more and more full as the afternoon wore on. There was so much great singing and excitement. Smiles were found not only on the field, but all around.

It was very cute seeing the really young girls (I think perhaps too young to participate) running out from the stands to march with them anyway, then running back even happier. Pairs and small groups of them would gather together and walk around the stands perhaps going between different people they knew in the seats.

At the end, the king came down and did his own dance and went around inspecting the groups. Some years he chooses a wife from those assembled, but not this year. I‚Äôm not really sure how all of that works but there is also input from his mother and various advisers so I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs as simple as just seeing a pretty girl.

It‚Äôs easy to see why this is such an important event for the Swazi people. It‚Äôs a wonderful showing of national pride and clearly an exciting event for the girls who participate. I‚Äôm glad we were able to see it during our time here.

item.title: Waterfalls and zebras
item.description:
We had a great trip on Saturday! We took a khumbi for a 30 minute ride to Malolotja Nature Reserve. It was an adventure just getting there since we weren‚Äôt entirely sure where to get off! Once there, we hiked around and explored under the watchful eyes of lots of gazelles (or impalas, we weren‚Äôt sure‚Ä¶). There were interesting rocks and lots of ups and downs

It was beautiful with good views. It was a hot day, but there were good breezes, especially on the hilltops.

In addition to the rocks, we saw lots of flowers in bloom as well.

After a few kilometers, we got to a lookout point where we thought we‚Äôd see the famed Malolotja Falls (highest in the country). It turned out that the overlook didn‚Äôt actually provide any view‚Ä¶ so that was disappointing. It was a beautiful view of the plains and valleys though. As we looked left, we noticed movement. We assumed it was more of the impalas or gazelles we kept seeing, but then we realized that we were seeing a herd of zebras! They were pretty far off, so I decided to try to approach them to get some photos. I walked slowly, and followed Karen‚Äôs advice to keep looking at the ground and ambling around more than just walking straight and looking at them. My ploy failed.

Every minute or so they‚Äôd start kicking up dust and jumping around, settling down a little farther away. Eventually, I gave up. Unfortunately, as with many cell phone cameras, I can‚Äôt really zoom so I don‚Äôt have any decent pictures to share. A real camera/lens combo would have yielded some great shots!

Past the zebras, we walked downhill, toward the waterfall. It was quite a bit farther than we‚Äôd hoped (even though we were warned!). It was a beautiful landscape, but much drier and open than we‚Äôre used to. We saw a sign for Ibis nesting. It said trail closed, but we had already been told by a ranger to ignore it. I‚Äôm assuming it just hadn‚Äôt been taken down yet.

The final part of the hike was a steeper decline. We got about halfway down and decided it was far enough since we could see it! We stood by an edge and got some shots.

It didn‚Äôt look that impressive from there, but we didn‚Äôt think it was a good idea to keep going and have to retrace that much more.

As we returned, we came across a patch of grass that was noticeably more lush. Getting closer we could tell that it was damp, saturated ground. Being on an incline and seeing this, with no stream or other water nearby seemed odd! Upon closer inspection, we saw that the water was bubbling up from under a rock! It was a little spring.

On the way back, I had to take a picture of the road. Talk about parched land! Despite the river and waterfall only a few kilometers away, there was no water here‚Ä¶

On the last leg of our hike, we noticed some very unusual rocks. I‚Äôve never seen cracks like these before, especially in so many rocks. I‚Äôm not sure what it means, but I know that Eswatini is supposed to be notable for geological reasons.

We made our way back to the road and had to wait a few minutes for the khumbi. The sun was starting to dip down so we started getting worried, but soon enough a ride came by! It was a fun day and we‚Äôre glad to have gotten to see some more of Eswatini‚Äôs natural beauty.

item.title: We thought our lives would be simple
item.description:
Hey, it‚Äôs been a while!

Back to School!

Since we last spoke, Gabriel and I have had a full week of school! In no particular order‚Ä¶

  • We went on a field trip today in our Buddhist History and Culture class. We walked five minutes down the road to a grand monastery that we hadn‚Äôt seen before. All 44 students settled into a small temple with three huge golden statues (sorry, no pictures allowed!) and read (aloud and in unison) the Buddha‚Äôs narration of his own enlightenment. What an excellent way to take advantage of the school‚Äôs location! Right behind us, several monks performed a puja (ceremony). We‚Äôd like to say that the traditional Tibetan horns playing in the background created a lovely spiritual atmosphere, but no, they were just super loud and clashed obnoxiously. Maybe we‚Äôll grow to like them??
  • We can now write in Devanagari (the Nepali alphabet)! Nepali class is definitely the most fun and engaging.
  • Khenpo class is neat. It‚Äôs less organized than I expected ‚Äî a learned Tibetan monk just talks about a text (‚ÄúThe Way of the Bodhisattva‚Äù by Shantideva), word by word, for 1.5 hours every day. We enjoy hearing his belly laugh, stories, friendly dialogue with the translator, and of course his vast stores of teachings.
  • Gabriel had his first Anthropology of Nepalese Religions class today with Fr. Greg. He says it was ‚Äúsuperb‚Äù, so especially because I‚Äôve taken a Buddhist Ethics class at OSU already, I think I‚Äôll switch out of Ethics to join Anthropology! I also plan to switch out of Buddhist History and Culture to join Fundamentals of Buddhist Philosophy.
  • On Saturday, we had exactly the sort of immersive experience we‚Äôd hoped for! First, we attended a 3.5-hour teaching by the esteemed Ch√∂kyi Nyima Rinpoche. He radiates compassion, and we received plenty of it because we sat in the very front with the other new students. He runs a 500-monk monastery, RYI, an online dharma training program, several dharma institutions outside of Nepal, a charity that helps people and animals in Nepal, and perhaps Earth. We would have enjoyed the teaching more if he hadn‚Äôt arrived a half hour late and we hadn‚Äôt been sitting painfully on the floor the entire time‚Ä¶ After the teaching, we met up with three classmates to work on a reflection paper over a ph·ªü lunch by the stupa. We had an amazing two-hour discussion with a nun of Korean heritage from New York, a nun from the Nepali side of the Himalayas, and a laywoman from the Kathmandu Valley. The first nun had zero patience for Western academic analysis of Buddhism, which was fascinating to hear and to (very sensitively) argue against. At one point, she gave a little speech about dance in Buddhism that perfectly mirrored something that Gabriel‚Äôs priest uncle had said to us a couple months ago about singing in Orthodox Christianity. All in all, super cool, and now we have a few new friends. (Tiring, though‚Ä¶ I fell asleep at 6:30pm that night.)
  • So much Buddhism. Although we‚Äôre glad that we‚Äôve set aside four months to study this fascinating subject, we definitely look forward to returning to computer science once we get home! This is actually the perfect situation ‚Äî we‚Äôre diving into another culture while affirming our career paths.

Boudha Community Choir

We found a choir!! Good news for my mental health!

We rehearse weekly at someone‚Äôs house. The choir has about 30 members, mostly from America and Europe. Many of them attend or teach at RYI. We‚Äôre preparing for a Christmas concert, and I think the choir is somehow associated with a local church; it‚Äôs really nice to have some exposure to familiar Western Christian culture. The choir isn‚Äôt gonna win any advanced musicianship awards, but that‚Äôs okay!

Best part: we‚Äôre singing ‚ÄúBogoroditse Devo‚Äù. During our wedding two months ago, the wedding choir sang it for us as we entered the church. So excited!

Swing Society

We taught a dance class! Yuki is an accomplished dancer and fellow member of the Corvallis Swing Society. She had the idea and motivation to begin a Swing Society at RYI. On Sunday, she, Gabriel, and I taught the basics of single-count swing to three students (we‚Äôll advertise better for next week) in the monastery restaurant‚Äôs meditation/activity room. They learned a ton in a short time, we hung out with a stray dog, I remembered to bring my portable speaker, we ran home in the pouring monsoon rain in the dark, and we had lots of fun.

Some slight updates/clarifications/corrections about the home situation

  1. Gabriel and I, as outcastes, are not allowed to be involved in the process of cooking in this high-caste (Brahmin) Hindu house. It‚Äôs fine if we are in the kitchen area. Our bedroom is ours, but the kitchen and dining room belong to the grandma. Her house, her rules. I have to let her know when I‚Äôm on my period so that she can serve me food in a room off to the side ‚Äî if I touched the dining table while I was on my period, I‚Äôd pollute it. (According to our Nepali language professor, many Brahmins these days are no longer this strict about purity.)
  2. The grandma has at least three ‚Äúhelpers‚Äù: Saili (always around), Laxmi (sometimes around), and a lady I just met today who apparently works in the garden. All of them are Brahmins. This explains why they are allowed to help in the kitchen!
  3. Again, all the purity stuff is Hindu; Buddhism doesn‚Äôt have castes. I‚Äôm writing about it because it‚Äôs striking to us, and it‚Äôs probably more interesting to read about than the way that Nepalis do their laundry or something.
  4. Roshan‚Äôs 12-year-old son, Pragoon, comes over pretty often, too. He and Ishan (Milan‚Äôs son; Pragoon‚Äôs cousin) are very close, and they play video games on their tablets together all the time.
  5. We still interact with only the grandma 90% of the time, and then only over meals. I really hope that we don‚Äôt seem antisocial!

Real Talk

After three weeks, my body is still having a hard time adapting to the new country. Sitting on the ground hurts ‚Äî I‚Äôm not sure whether to blame weak back muscles or scoliosis. I‚Äôve needed a lot of sleep: upwards of 9 hours every day. The humidity makes us sweat and makes the scary-disease-carrying mosquitos happy. I‚Äôm glad that we aren‚Äôt expected to go on adventures across the city now that orientation is over, because those taxed me to my physical and mental limit. Gabriel and I have both had mild colds and severe headaches. We‚Äôre very glad that we haven‚Äôt had any stomach bugs or severe illnesses (yet)! Sometimes we‚Äôve struggled to find enough time alone to recharge our introverted selves. We‚Äôve had to adapt to different food: the current meal plan is a large serving of dal bhat tarkari (rice or flatbread, lentils, and various vegetable curries) in the morning, a small serving of whatever-the-monastery-restaurant-happens-to-have-today at 12:30, and another large serving of dal bhat tarkari in the late evening.

I say all this not to complain, but to show that moving across the world has physical consequences, even if you don‚Äôt get sick! Travelers, please take care; people at home, enjoy your ability to more easily take care üôÇ

item.title: Yosakoi Festival
item.description:
Since all of last week was a holiday, there were lots of festivals all over the place for different things depending on the day. There were a bunch of fireworks festivals later in the week, but on Sunday afternoon was a dance festival.

We arrived at the festival mid afternoon and as we walked up, there was a very intense group of girls (middle school I think?) from one of the local schools performing in the streets. This style of dance involves moving forward quite far, so the festival was setup at a T intersection: the top part of the T was where two different groups would perform separately as they moved toward the middle, the bottom of the T was a large main stage where different groups would perform, and the intersection of the T was where all the food stalls were.

We grabbed a bit of food and watched a bunch of different performances, we were both super impressed with the flag waving. Each troup had 1-3 flag wavers at the back of the group and their flags were huge. I can‚Äôt imagine how much strength it must have taken to wave the flags like they were, but they were all ripped.

We arrived right at the end of all the performances, so we got to see the big finale where all the troupes performed together twice, and then afterwards all the flag bearers came out, they introduced all the groups, then did a performance with just the flags twice.

I‚Äôm not sure if Lilly will approve of me uploading these, but there was also a group all the way from Hokkaido (some from Sendai as well, this was apparently a well known event) who took things up a notch. At one point in their main performance, the men all stripped down to their loin clothes and finished the dance like that. Of course during the combined performance at the end, they excitedly repeated that aspect of their show for everyone to enjoy.
